I've been all over the Steam store and I've been playing PC games since the 80's, with a particular interest in the medieval eras. You won't find a game that allows you more freedom in a sandbox medieval setting than this. This can be one of the best games you'll ever play, if you are adventurous and enjoy making up your own scenarios and backstories. If a guided experience is more your vibe, this won't be your cup of tea because it has no main quest line or any real defined goals outside of being your character.  Gameplay is fantastic and the combat is intuitive, with a variety of modifiers should any aspect be too easy or too hard for personal taste. The menus are a little lacking and can be confusing to navigate, but a few hours of play and it comes together. The variety of weapons is great, and having taken the time to read up on how to command troops in battle I feel that while it isn't immediately accessible it isn't terribly obtuse, either.  As if the core game for the price wasn't enough, the mod scene is amazing. Try North South and fight in the American Civil War. Prefer playing in a low fantasy Europe setting? Sure, there are mods for that. Vikings? Bryntwalda. Or maybe you prefer Lord of the Rings as a setting? Yup. That and Game of Thrones both have mods that allow you to truly inhabit these worlds as anyone from a peasant to the highest of Kings. And there are many, many more.  The only thing I see dethroning this as medieval sim king anytime soon is Mount & Blade: Bannerlord.

Wonderful - all be it a bit square - sandbox game. Start your own warband in a medival world and emerge as a glorious leader, lord, king, bandit, trader...you name it. Choose your destiny amongst 6 unique factions each of them with their own mentality and troops, or assemble a mighty army from all realms, be a trader or mercenary to a faction or become vassal to a King or even become a King yourself - choices are nigh infinite. You can replay this game an infinite amount of times with different settings and it will remain interesting, and on top of that you can modify certain aspects of the game or go for one of the many mods out there ranging from all kinds epoches and additions (i must admit that M&B 1 fares a little better what regards the amount and quality of mods released). There are some downers: You will experience clipping and other graphic absurdities every now and then, it is not perfect. The AI is a bit dumb-witted at times, in terms of field movements and tactical behaviour - the latter does not really exist actually, it is just troops spawning running towards one another and starting to beat each other up, it is up to you to be better than them. There is a saying that 'a lot of good work is lost over the lack of a little more', this is found to be true here as the grid for many diplomatic and military game options is actually present - it is just not used well by the vanilla game and left for modders to patch up. The modders in turn often work on their own vision of how the game should be but then lacking the manpower to achieve their conveyed goals. Good examples for this might be the 'Sword of Damocles'-Series which is wonderful yet stricken with bugs on M&B 1, and in a seemingly eternal unfinished-we-are-working-on-it-but-play-this-in-the-meantime process on M&B:Warband. Taleworld wanted to encourage modding for this game, but failed to provide an easily accessible scripting interface for modders to work with. This results in a game that is never 100% satisfying in vanilla, and a bunch of mods that aim to provide that satisfaction but fail half-way due to lack of manpower.  Nevertheless i must say i enjoy this game tremendously glad i bought it (M&B Package) as it offers a completly different feel of gaming compared to most more action-oriented games these days. No big explosions or noisy shooting and blurred vision and other mess, just a nice game with nice and sometimes funny NPCs and an eye for the neat things in life as well as a semi-realistic view on what life and war in medival ages might have been like. 8/10

Mount & Blade: Warband is the second installment in the Mount & Blade franchise.  -You may find a simple review below the main review with the pros and cons of the game.   Warband added many new features from the original, and one of the largest was multiplayer. Multiplayer is in my opinion Warband's strongest attribute. The PvP combat is excellent, the maps are well made, and the experience overall is superb. Battles are large and epic, ranging from perhaps 10 people on each side to over 100. The vast array of weapons to use assures a new experience every time you play - everything from One Handed Swords, One Handed Axes, Spears, Bows, Crossbows, Javelins, and huge War Cleavers. Each faction (six in all) has a unique loadout, which adds a unique flavour aswell. Sieges are also quite ferocious and time consuming, some taking almost an hour or more. Combat involves a four-directional combat system, and a simple but practical approach to projectile drop. The community for this game is amazing, although players in Asia and North America may find slight problems finding populated servers due to the majority of players being centered in the EU. The Singleplayer is fun, but very repetitive. Your objective is to have the entire map controlled by one faction or your own. You can do a variety of quests for lords, kings, and villages - but are all repetitive. The character levelling is good, with a good array of choices to make your character how you like. A variety of different mods that are available for this game adds to the replay value of both the Multiplayer and Singleplayer aspects.   Pros +Intuitive Combat +Great Mounted Combat +Sounds and Soundtrack are superb +Singleplayer has wonderful RPG elements +Many mods and additions to add hours of fun to the game  Cons -Aging Graphics -Hit Detection can be a bit sloppy -Does not have DirectX 11 support (DirectX 7 & 9 only) -Smaller community than most games -Singleplayer has many repetitive aspects and quests (which can sometimes be snuffed with mods)  Overall Rating: 8.5/10 (Good game, has a few flaws)

Mount & Blade: Warband (along with its predecessor, Mount & Blade) is a game so unique it is difficult to fit it snugly into one category. It's an action RPG, it's grand strategy, it's a simulation, it's open world. This game is a whole bunch of things that melt so perfectly together, and it is unlike any other game I've ever played. For anyone who is even the slightest bit interested in medieval warfare, this is the game you never knew you wanted.  You start out by answering some simple questions about the life your character has lived thus far, and critiquing the way your heroine (or hero) looks. You are thrown into the large continent of Calradia which is split into six unique factions that are constantly at war with each other. The world map is familiar to those of us who enjoy grand strategy games; you can view the land and the castles/towns/villages/hideouts etc. that exist on it at any one time, while your character and her horse moves along it like a pawn on a gameboard. The colors of the names tell you which faction currently owns and controls each piece of land. What you begin to do from here is ultimately up to you. You can try doing favors for lords and kings to win their favor and ultimately work for them, whilst building up a small army of ragtag soldiers that you recruit and hire from various places, or you can be bold and try almost immediately to begin taking over land yourself (which I wouldn't recommend for the first dozen or so hours into the game).  Battles in this game are nothing short of amazing. Both warring sides start out on opposite ends of the map (I've never seen the same battlefield twice, by the way, so I believe they are randomized based on the terrain type you are currently traversing). You can issue commands to your army, and this is fun to mess around with. For example, you can tell your archers to stand their ground and your cavalry to charge the enemy, while giving a different order to infantry. It's all up to you. By default, all units will charge, and for the most part, this is sufficient. You will then meet your enemy in the battlefield, where cavalry can run over infantry, archers can shoot riders off of horses, and you can kill horses while their riders are still living, making them fall face first into the ground before swarming them. Basically, if you've ever seen two opposing sides charge in a movie and have felt that intensity and awe, you can actually play as one of those people involved in Mount & Blade, and each and every time it's amazing. This game is fantastic for nerds like me who love anything medieval; not only are there full out battles like this, but you eventually (and your army) get strong enough to take over castles, towns, etc., and you get to be one of the units that is a part of this, each and every single time.  The goal regardless seems to be to take over the entire map of land, whether through an existing faction or through your own, which you may create once you have a strong enough army to begin taking over land by force. Lords will double cross you, downright insult you, and even beg their respective kings for the rights to a castle you may have taken over yourself, and depending on the circumstance, you may or may not be jipped out of a piece of land you worked hard for. You can then, however, decide to accept that or give a one fingered salute to your king before renouncing your allegiance and going your own way. It is entirely up to you.  I would highly, highly recommend you play as a woman character, even if you are not a woman in real life. The game is fantastic at reflecting the negative attitudes toward women at the time, and those mentalities can highly influence you during the game. For example, I created a woman character and named her after myself, much like I did for the first Mount and Blade. I set about leveling up my character and recruiting soldiers, and picked up a mercenary contract for a faction. After taking over three castles single-handedly for the faction's king, I spoke to the king, introduced myself, and asked to be promoted to being his vassal. He told me outright that he didn't care what I had accomplished. Because I was a woman, I could not be his vassal, and I couldn't own land. I asked him what would happen if I took an enemy castle by force, and he replied that he would 'think about' letting me keep it. This sexist attitude (although very realistic for the time) got me so fired up that I promptly cancelled my contract with the king and began taking over his land by force. After about 40 hours of in-game time, he was exiled from the land, his faction was extinct, and all of his land belonged to a new faction appropriately named 'Rosie's Kingdom of Awesome.' About 40 hours after that, I was Queen of Calradia. But it all started because of my motivation to overthrow an arrogant and sexist king as the woman he insulted, and no other game has done such a great job of inspiring me to create my own grudges and follow through on them until I conquered all.   This game is one of the most perfectly put together pieces of work I've ever played. I've seen people question the graphics, but I think the game is simplisticly beautiful (also, I grew up in the 90s--graphics don't matter to me). The game runs perfectly on my older non-gaming laptop, so that's also a plus for those of you looking for a large scale warfare game that can play on a toaster. There are some glitches, although nothing game-breaking (people spawned on the outside of a castle wall in 2/500 or so sieges I played, and I once had to sit out one siege because I fell through a crack in a floor of a castle tower and floated perpetually until my soldiers won the battle without me and I could exit). The character animations are a bit stiff, but I actually like them that way; it brings humor to the game for me, and if any future Mount & Blade doesn't have the stiff animations, I'll miss them.  Mount & Blade: Warband took 90 hours of my life away in the past week, and very few games can pull me in so relentlessly. This game is one of my personal favorites, along with Mount & Blade (I haven't tried With Fire & Sword yet, but it's only a matter of time). A solid 10/10 from me. Buy this game. Buy it now, and let it consume you. :)

I cannot recommend this game highly enough. One of the most exhilirating and satisfying gaming experiences you will ever have. A glorious combination of deep combat mechanics, kingdom management, and sandbox roleplay, there's really no other game like it in existence.Since its release many games have tried to capture the format to varying degrees.   I have enjoyed watching this game develop from a sleeper hit to a bona fide 'must-play' title over the years.The combat is brutal and intense. There is no hand-holding, and even though you can change the difficulty it is still realistic because no matter how well-armored your character might be, you can still be brought down by a well-placed spear thrust or arrow. The closest thing to experiencing medieval combat outside of the Society for Creative Anachronism.  The mods Floris Mod Pak, A Clash of Kings, and 1257 AD push the envelope and expand the gameplay in exciting new ways.   Buy it during the next steam sale, you will not be disappointed.  Many people play this strictly for the multiplayer, which is worth it by itself. What exactly is Mount & Blade? Partly it is a medieval fighting simulator, partly role playing game and partly a strategy game. All of this is present in this huge chunk of buggy code wrapped in mediocre graphics. But that is little too harsh, because this game has something to overcome all of this. Flawless gameplay.  You start by creating your character in not too deep creator. There is couple of background choices which will determine your stats. Stats are the RPG part of the game, you get all the basics like strenght, agility and intelligence, followed by skills that determine your abiliy to hold shields, ride a horse or get better prices from traders. At the very last there are the weapon stats, those are here to tell you how well you will fare with different kind of weapons. You can choose between bows, crossbows, short or long swords, spears and polearms.  After you are done spending your points, you get a piece of the fighting simulator. You get thrown into an one on one fight without any sort of tutorial, this game is expansion after all, so you should already know everything right? Well, in case you did not play the original... Generally you use left mouse button for attacking and right mouse button for defending. That's pretty common right? But that is obviously not everything. By moving the mouse to either of four directions (right, left, up, down) prior to the swing you determine the manner of the attack. To add more fun to this, you can do the same while defending, so basically you have to check your opponent's movement and react fast enough to block. However if you are not up to the challenge you can use automatic blocking, in this case you will only need to time the block and the direction will be automatically chosen by computer. So that's it, quite simple is it not? Other weapons are similar with small differences mostly in possible manners of attacking. Ranged weapons are even more challenging. There is no aim indicator and arrows, bolts or javelins respect the laws of gravity, so it will take a while to get used to it.  Well, that was quite elaborate description of fighting system, I hope I did not bore you. This leaves us with strategy part of the game. So yeah, after you finish your first fight you get your first quest (yep, another sign of rpg) and end up on a huge map, not too unlike Total War world maps, but way uglier, and move your character around. Everything is in real time, but since the time stops everytime your character stops, in principle the game is more similar to turnbased games. So there you are on a huge map, large groups of enemies moving around you. You may try to challenge one of the groups yourself and find out, that you are no hero, just another warrior who gets butchered when facing more than 2 or 3 enemies at once. At this point you get to one of the villages and recruit yourself a bunch of peasants. Soon enough you will find that peasants are more like meat shields and die a lot, but with a piece of luck and good commander (you) they can make it as far as to knighthood. This all sounds more like tactics than strategy right (wink)? Well, to be honest I am not sure how it works in vanilla (unmodded) game, since after original Mount & Blade, in Warband I started with mods right away.  Yes, mods are the greatest thing that could have happened to this game. The basics are great but the game itself needed helluva lot of polishing to become a legend. There are tons of mods ready to be tried and some of them are really robust. I myself am using Floris mod pack (to be find on  nexusmods.com)  which combines many different mods improving graphics and gameplay alike. And the strategy part I was talking about is part of this mod, since in here, before the fight starts you get to strain your mind by choosing how will your units behave during the battle. You had probably already guessed that I think that Mount & Blade: Warband is a good game, well you are right, but with mods, it becomes a GREAT game.

This game never fails providing me with the medieval atmosphere when I need it. Creating a new character in this game is a joy. When you just start creating your new character and send it to the world you are confronted with so many little decisions and adventures that you can take on many approaches. Be a soldier, a merchant, an outlaw or an adventurer - You can do it! The first 10-20 hours in any game are simply pure fun and all are unique in their way. Choosing your lord is exciting, joining a war is exciting, attending tournaments is exciting - it is all just great and has a unique feel that sits just right.  However, the game seem to stop giving an effort at late-game, once you become strong enough to be a lord which is the one and only end-game scenario you can achieve, things become dull and repetetive. You will go about the same way from castle to castle as you slowly see the map turning your color. Expect no suprises, there will be none as politics barely exist and every war can be calculated and work as expected. Once you have the leverage over the game it will stay there and the game basically ends.   The tactics are nice in this game. There are alot of ways to go about into battle and a combination of skill and strategy is needed to curve through a rough enemy. However the AI that is against you is pettiful at best and will always act similiar in terms of strategy, making it too easy to manipulate. there are only handful of scenarios and tactics you need to grasp and once you get familliar with them managing the battle becomes just another repetetive thing.  The economy is also nice, however getting too much into it doesn't help you by much and you can probably profit better by just killing stuff. I still like it being there.  Alot of design flaws... Auto resolved battles between AI is pure ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, it almost does not matter(if at all) which type of troops battle against which type of other troops or it the battle was a siege or an open battle. The AI gets more money than you by having cities and castles which breaks immersion and breaks their whole point of logical economic system and makes you feel as you are treated as a player rather than a character within the world. Diplomacy is merely a joke, there is nothing interesting to do with prisoners. Being captured always ends the same way for you. Characters can't die. Killing bandits is too profitable and destroying their hideouts usually gives you nothing and stops their spawn which is anti intuitive and kills profit. I can go on for ever with the design flaws of this game, but it is expected from a small company.  I mention all this flaws just to say I still recommend this game, because understanding flaws is easy for a reader but understanding the sense of wonder and atmosphere I get each time i open a new character is beyond simple words and I think you should buy the game to experience that.

Mount and Blade:Warband is a open-world sandbox rpg that gives you the freedom to do whatever you want at any time.   Some examples of how Warband does this are: You may ally with any faction you wish so long as you have sufficient reputation.Marry a lady to increase your standing and hold feast's. Compete in tournaments to earn fame and fortune.Roam the countryside hunting bandits or become one yourself. You can raid villages for loot and plunder. You may sell your sword to the highest bidder and change allegiances on a whim.You may even start your own faction if you so wish.  Variety is the primary ingredient in mount and blade. Forge your destiny with blade or diplomacy the choice is yours.  Combat is the other major selling point for this title. Combat is a tense experience due to the fact that no matter how powerful you become one mistake can lead to a crushing defeat if you are careless.  This title offers tons gameplay for the price you can easily sink hundreds of hours into this game. If you should ever grow tired of the gameplay simply buy a expansion that offers a whole new experience and you are good to go.

Mount & Blade: Warband is my second most played game so I thought it was appropriate that I make a review. Mount & Blade as a series is good but I would argue that Warband is the best. Warband captures a unique playstyle in which your AI units are not commpletely helpless. In a lot of other bot reliant games, I see that you always have to clean up after your bots and they can't really do anything on their own. In Warband, I could easily stroll around in the back of the map while my soldiers win for me. Even though I do not play so much as I used to, this is a game I play for the relaxing factor of single player.  After playing a fair bit of single player, I moved on to multiplayer. Warband has one of the most brutal transitions from single to multiplayer that I have ever experienced. TLDR: If you want to play one of the best games ever, you should buy this game. I promise you won’t regret it.  Now that Warband is the first game I've put 1,000 hours on I want to write a review saying just how much I have loved the game. I can honestly say, without a doubt, that Warband is the best game I have ever played and is one of my favorite games ever. Now I am 24 years old and in law school but I have been playing the game since I was 19, and a freshman in college so understand that I have a tremendous love for the game. First we'll start with the good things about the game.  The best thing about the game is the incredible amount of replayability of the game. In the base game alone you can easily put 500 hours in on the game due to the countless options you have in playing the game. You want to play as a mercenary working for whoever pays the most? You can. Do you want to work for a singular nation and take over the entire world for them? You can. Do you want to become the empire of the entire world? You can. Do you want to be a knight, or a Mongol, or an archer, or a crossbowman, or a merchant, or a Viking, or anything in between? Whatever you want to be you can be. The game is a complete sandbox where the world is constantly changing and you find yourself in the center of it all.   The next best thing about the game is the amount of mods that the modding community has created. Do you like Game of Thrones? There’s a mod for that. Are you a fan of Star Wars (like myself)? There’s a mod for that. Are you interested in a more historical mod based on the crusades, or Ancient Rome, or the Trojan war, or Turn of the century Russia, or the Napoleonic era? There are mods for that. If you’re more interested in a high fantasy/Tolkien style? There are numerous mods for that. You are only limited by what you are looking for in a mod, and most of the mods are great. That at least doubles the replayability of the game.  Another great thing about the game is the multiplayer capability of the game. The game has some of the best multiplayer that I’ve ever experienced. Both the vanilla game, and the DLC include multiplayer versions that you can play. The mechanics of multiplayer can be difficult to learn, and even more difficult to master but when you get good at the combat the multiplayer becomes even more fun. The Napoleonic Wars DLC is a great value especially if/when you join a regiment for the game. I’ve met people from the ages of 10-60+ playing multiplayer and a lot of them are very cool people. I started playing multiplayer in February and just under half my hours are multiplayer now.  Now we will talk about some of the areas the game is slightly problematic. The biggest turn off for people is generally the very basic graphics of the game. Warband itself if 6 years old, and the graphics were already dated when it came out so the graphics have not aged well. If you are someone who refuses to play a game unless it has the best graphics this game is certainly not for you. Another turn off is that some of the mechanics are a little off, due to its age. The rag dolls are usually awful, and the AI is even worse, however sometimes the AI and ragdolls can create some great and humorous memories. Furthermore the initial difficulty of the game can turn people off from it, because the game is NOT easy; as soon as you learn how to play though it is a great game that you will not get tired of easily.  The other bad part of the game kind of goes hand in hand with the multiplayer modes in the game. A lot of the Warband community (particularly the NW community) is toxic in every sense of the word. Imagine CoD community, heightened by the difficulty of the game. The community is oftentimes terrible, however if you join a group or a regiment you find a new layer of the community. For me, I joined the 21st Regiment of Foot in February and ever since I have loved playing multiplayer and have made countless friends through the regiment. If you find a group to play with the community becomes actually quite fun.  Ultimately I cannot stress enough how great the game is, and it is pretty cheap as well especially when you get it on sale. The game itself goes on sale all the time and if you can find it for under 10$ it will be one of the best 10$ you will ever spend. When I first got the game I got it on sale for 5$ and have well made up for that price in hours played. So in the end if you want to play one of the best games ever, you should buy this game. I promise you won’t regret it.

This one is interestig, in a good way. Mount & Blade places you in a far away medival land with nothing but your wit, a horse, some weapons and some clothes. There are some factions you can join and fight for, but the point of the game is that you don't NEED to. There is no finite goal. Want to become the king of the land and rule the entire map? Sure can do. Want to be a bandit king and stike fear in the hearts of trade caravans? Sure can do. Want to be a lowly soldier in some army and fight for the money? Sure can do.  M&B is a sandbox game, a damned good one too. The combat is easy to learn, yet hard to master and very satisfying, and also very adjustable to your preferred playstyle. Blocking is a challenge in itself on higher difficulties, and fighting multiple enemies at once can be really hard if you are alone. Being outnumbered can end up with you taken as a prisoner (you can't die in battle or be sold to slavery, you will escape sooner or later and have to start from scratch), but luckily, if you don't like that sort of thing, you can set the enemies to only do half or a fifth of the damage that you can do.  The only negative thing that I have is the AI. When you are travelling across the map, the AI will attempt to follow paths DESPERATELY. Even if that means that you will run into an enemy and get slaughtered, all for a measly 0.5 speed increase for walking on roads. Similarly, the combat AI is also not the greatests. Your allies will not attempt to hold a strategic position, such as a mountain, but rather charge right into the enemy.  Oh yeah, and the graphics suck. Low quality textures and an extremely low amount of polygons per model. It works, don't get me wrong, but it is not pretty. The trailer is very accurate when it comes to graphics.  The sound design is very nice, good and fitting music and neat combat screams. You can even extract the music from a folder and ctrl-c ctrl-v them somewhere else so you can listen to your favorite soundtracks whenever you want to.  With mod support this one is easily worth the money, maybe wait for a sale and get it with all expansions for around 20$/€. Thats what I did.

This game is quite amazing. I've never seen something quite like it. Its an open world sandbox for medeviel politics and combat. Wondering around growing your forces, going to tournaments, causing intrigue with the local lords, raiding villages, fighting in wars. Those are the kinds of things you primarily do. Its surprisingly much more satisfying than Rome Total War, where you start to dread entering battles. Clobbering through enemies never really gets old, although infantry to infantry combat could stand some improvement (the game is built around riding on a horse, as per the name). Think of it as Dynasty Warriors Total War with a faint hint of Crusader Kings.  There's a lot of different approaches in playstyle, army composition, etc. So while I imagine there's a lot of replay value in the full game (seems like it would take quite a long time to become king or have your faction take over the world), you'll probably want to play it again to take another approach.  All in all, its easy to get into, and doesn't seem to get boring, even though I played the demo for about double my steam time a few years ago.

What is Mount & Blade Warband? but honestly, what is it not? Mount and blade may be the greatest simulation war game I've played maybe ever. The game has defined the idea of starting small and rising up. With an endless amounts of paths, falls, twists and turns to get to that goal.   The game will challenge your tolerance to difficulty and time management in life (I've missed dates for this game)   The game will throw you into a never peaceful land of Caldaria  The game will have you lead your 500 man army against another 500, or a castle or an entire city. You know the beach scene from Saving Private Ryan? Like that except you're there with way more bloodshed.  The game will have you staring at the screen for minutes to hours questioning ever decision made. Will it screw you over? Will it give you more power? Are you greedy? Evil? You choose my friend.  The game will have you owning an entire empire. The empire's cost being up to you.   The game will allow you to choose what to do with the other factions. Do you side with them? Create a diplomacy? Split the continent in 1/2 or maybe less? Or do you sweep the land?  The game will have you hiding behind your castle walls as perhaps hundreds and maybe a thousand men are throwing up ladders and sieging your walls, burning your towns.  But most importantly, the game will fill your whole of power, accomplishment and overall fulfillment of a great sandbox game that will forever go in history. If you can buy the game. If you are still biased, try the demo. I promise that it will be worth your while :)

Mount and Blade has been a great way to kill time. It takes time to play, time to learn. Pros: -You are capable of affecting the real time economy and global status of nations throughout the entire game. Everything you do for one nation affects the nation as a whole, often times other nations as well.  -Character development and Party development can't be understated in this game. Everything from the major characters to the soldiers and hirelings in your party gain experience and fight alongside you in the battlefield. It's astounding when it comes to massive battles. Entire fortresses may fall beneath your banner, or you might simply be shot down at their walls, depending on your choices and party configurations.  -An incredibly simple, but somehow intricate diplomacy system that allows you to gain nobility and make alliances within nations, from gaining foothold for your king or leader, to staging an uprising to overthrow him. It has troubles doing almost anything on it's own, with a lot of trouble from navigating simple terrain. Though I do have to say it is 100X better then the first game, as in the original the AI couldn't even navigate most castles. While this can be ignroed mostly, it will cause a little anger towards those moments when a unit could have secured victory but failed to do the simplest task.  -Play trackng. Maybe I'm just paranoid, but it seems the AI tracks the player. When in the arena, I've noticed groups of enemies breaking off from a fight just to follow me, getting up to 4+ people attacking me at once. And it doesn't seem to be based off of any in-game factors, as from start to finish it seems to remain the same. This can make combat extremely difficult for the player, as it is hard to fight off multiple troops when they are set on killing you alone.  -Feels unfinished. Many aspects of the game feel like they were being created, but ceased so the game could release. While it isn't too big a problem, you will clearly see some things that should have been worked on.  -Forced opening quest. Unlike the original where you start off by a training field, you are forced to kill a bandit and meet the merchant. Mount & Blade: Warband  is the best medieval simulation I've ever played. The way it was executed was excellent and TaleWorlds deserves nothing but praise for the obvious effort they've put into this game. Though the graphics are nothing to be marvelled at (for good reason), the gameplay is great: The combat is fluid and responsive, with a focus on perfect hitboxes and timing attacks, and the make-your-own adventure feeling of the game adds to it's fun and political based world. I bought this game some months back and at first I simply could not put it down, clocking over 50 hours within the first week and a half! The game is truly addicting by nature.  Though the graphics are nothing to marvel at, the game still looks good in what it's intended purpose is: massive scale battles in which you control a sole character amongst hundreds of soldiers on a battlefield. If the graphics were too over the top, I could see many framerate issues on older machines. However it's something you don't really notice because you're too busy hacking and slashing your way to victory. Each battlefield is fully rendered and require  no loading times past the initial load , which is impressive for how varied each of the environments are. Each castle in the game is unique, and there are dozens of them to siege and take for your particular faction. There are also dozens of cities which also have their own unique look and style which can also be sieged and taken for yourself.  The combat is fantastic. It's responsive and the hitboxes are perfect. If some one shoots an arrow at your side and it hits your shield, it will hit your shield eventhough you don't have it raised. If some one shoots you in the back while your shield is on your back, the shield will protect you from the arrow. If you attack from the left and your opponent blocks to their left, you'll land a hit. If yout attack to the left and the opponent blocks to their right, they'll block your attack. You can also feint an attack to make it seem like you're attacking from a certain direction and then come in with a strike from the opposite direction, tricking your opponent into blocking themselves on the wrong side, scoring yourself a hit. It's things like this that make the combat interesting and challenging, as it has a certain amount of depth to it that will keep you guessing on what your opponent is going to do next.  The make-your-own adventure style is strong with this one. You can literally do anything you feel like, as it is an open sandbox style of game. Want to join one of the warring kingdoms to help your leader achieve dominance over the domain of Calradia? You most certainly can. Want to create your own faction to vie for power yourself and take the throne of Calradia for your own? Of course you can do that too. Want to be a brigand and rob caravans, and amass a fortune to rival even the wealthiest of kingdoms? Go ahead. There is a lot of creative freedom in what you can do in the game, which encourages multiple playthroughs with characters that have different skill sets.  The game also supports online multiplayer which is very smooth and runs very well. Participating in massive scale battles where every soldier is a player is a blast, and where the game truly shines as people are much more clever than any AI could be, making the multiplayer the most challenging part of the game. There are still plenty of people that are online in the multiplayer portion of the game, so don't let the release date of the game fool you; people are still very much active in the online portion of the game.  The game also has several DLC expansions (I have the viking conquest expansion, which is a lot of fun) that change up the gameplay immenseley. Fire and Ice adds guns to the game, which completely revolutionizes ranged combat (like it did in the real world), Viking conquest adds longboat battles, so you can now take to the sea and fight other vikings in large scale longboat warfare. The game is also fully moddable and you can find plenty of them to keep the game fresh and interesting no matter how long you've been playing it for.  Overall, it doesn't get much better than this in the medieval simulation genre. If that's your thing I could not recommend Warband more. If I were to give it a rating it would be 9/10, the only thing holding it back from a perfect score being the graphics. You're guaranteed to get dozens of hours of enjoyment from this title if you love medieval simulation, if not hundreds of hours for the most infatuated. The combat system is impeccable, the make your own adventure style is done very well, the freedom to create your own story is present, the online multiplayer is alive and well, and being able to mod the game keeps it fresh and interesting for multiple playthroughs.  In conclusion, buy this game. You will not regret it. I've only had the game for a short time and it quickly became one of my favourite games ever made. If you're a fan of medieval simulation, you owe it to yourself to experience  Mount & Blade: Warband

The Mount and Blade series could be defined as indie: the mechanics, and strategy element are familiar with most gamers (same controls and strategy as most FPS's) yet put a experienced CoD fan on the mouse and their KD ratio will prove that it actually takes skill and knowledge to defeat the enemy. Unlike your large corporate FPS, with individuals rushing around competing not only with their enemy but their fellow teammates to present the highest KD on the leaderboards. Mount and Blade (MB) will offer tactics and teamwork to the players who found it difficult manoevering around a quick succession of buttons to jump and no-scope your way out of a close encounter with the opposing team. The large scale warfare wil re-inact the deadly elements of the medieval battlescene, with servers supporting games of over 200 other combatents. I highly recommend purchasing the Napoleonic Wars DLC, unlike CoD's similar priced DLC which grants you access to a few extra maps, this DLC could be sold as a seperate game, and yes, their are new maps being added nearly every day thanks to user modification which are moderated by secure servers. Mount and Blade is a fantastic game that combines attributes of Sandbox, light RPG, and real time strategy to a seemless medieval world.  What I like about warband is there are various different activities in the fictious world of Caldaria, from figthing bandits, to playing politics, trade, arena fighting, or even starting your own rouge nation from the ground up.  I also really like how the combat works, because you can control which direction your character attacks and with weapons you have to match attack directions with block directions to make the most out of melee combat. Ranged combat also has some interesting features where it takes into account your movement and projectile drop off when taking shots. That light RPG aspect comes into play also as your character gets stronger, faster, and more precise as you develop his skills, making him either into a lethal warrior, an agile bowman, or a cunning tactician. Which gives the game a lot of flexibilty as to how you go about it.  The world is a true sandbox in that it doesn't require you to do anything or go certain ways, but gives you all the tools to make things happen your way but also have the world adapt to your actions in a way that forces you to continually change your tactics when approaching situations.  I myself have sunk hundreads of hours into this game and have reccomended it to everyone I know on steam. I would even go as far as to say that this is one of my favorite games of all time. This is definitely a must own game, and if your not aware of it and like hack/slash gameplay with character skill progression give it a shot.

A lot of my friends on steam ask me about this title so I decided to rewrite my initial review, so here goes.  Let me start off by saying that Mount & Blade Warband is a great game.  The game is set in the dark ages with 6 Factions spread over Calradia which is the only world you will know for a couple of days once you start playing this game.  This game is highly addictive and once you get hooked you won't be able to stop.  The aim of the game is to conquer Calradia and you can either join up with a faction and help them fight to conquer all of Calradia or you can start your own faction and become the ruler yourself or the last option is joining a Claimant to one of the 6 factions and retake their throne but the game is not as easy as it sounds.  You start off with just you alone and the history you choose at character creation will determine what skills and inventory items you have at game start, from there you start recruiting soldiers and companions to help further your cause in the many third or first person battles you will have and even though there are many companions in Calradia not all of them get along so it will take some time to figure out how to manage them.   As you progress through the game the types of battles you have changes from fighting bandits and pirates in the start to gear up and make some gold to full on castle and town sieges. When you start you attack groups of bandits anywhere between 5 - 15 bandits in a group, but as the game progresses and you level up your character and companions and get bigger armies the battles sometimes scale to 2000+ troops. With only your horse and your choice of weaponry ranging from Bows, Crossbows, Lances, Axes, Swords, Maces and Throwing weapons like daggers & Javelins the fun is endless.   This game will take up a lot of your time especially if you decide to start your own faction or claim Calradia for a claimant. But it is time well spent.  There are also thousands of mods for this game that opens new worlds for conquering.   1 Mod I will definately reccomend for the base game is the Diplomacy Mod, it doesn't change the core game at all but gives you more speech options and outcomes when treating and talking with other vassals & kings. In my opinion Diplomacy Mod is a must have.  My Rating - 10/10 It simply is a awesome game.

I have to say that this might be my current favorite game. I have totally lost my life to it, since in only 3 days I have almost 20 hours logged in it.   If you are the kind of gamer that likes; middle ages, fast paced melee combat, managing a kingdom (I don't have one yet, I only have 2 villages after 20 hours.) large good looking maps with up to hundreds of units hacking it out. Then you will most likely love this game.  As a disclaimer I have a brand new high end gaming computer, so if you system is at or just better then the reccommended you might have issues, I don't know, all I know is that I don't have a single flaw when I play. I also have yet to play any multiplayer, so if you want to know about that you might want to read another review.  Some quick pros and cons.  Pros; +A long and tricky balance working your way up in the ranks of your chosen faction. (lots of gameplay) +Smooth fastpaced melee and ranged combat. +Simple easy to use controls. +Many different job/quest types. (Adds some varity.) +Large army were each unit thinks and acts on its own, or follows simple commands. (Follow me, Charge, Fall back, ect. (Default is charge.)) +The chance to go from peasant or son (or daughter) of a fallen lord to as high as King. +Defeat isn't the end! You are only captured, loose your normal troops, some gold and an item or 2. Then you get released or escape. (if you get another army you can free your captured troops.) +Free troop training, and you get exp as well. (Go-to a training camp and spar with your troops to train them. No gold needed.)  Cons; -No autosave, so make sure you save OFTEN! -Female faces are UGLY! (the male faces arn't bad) -Some starts are unplayable. (step out of the first town on your first quest to get troops, and get attacked by bandits. I had this happen 3 times in a row.) -After your army grows, sometimes you cannot complete some quests, because your too slow to catch up to a target. -No multiplayer in main campaign. (would have been pretty easy with a few minor changes to time progression.) -Not alot of varity. Kill some bandits. buy some troops. Train troops. Buy/steal food. Train troops. Sack a village. Fight off raiding armies. Buy troops. ect. -Hard to make gold when your faction is at peace.  Thats all I can think of off the top of my head, time to go back and keep playing.  Overall 7/10 (multiplayer in main campaign would make it 8.)

Mount & Blade: Warband - a Sophisticated Review  WARNING: MOUNT AND BLADE SERIOUSLY HARMS YOU AND OTHERS AROUND YOU Do not buy/play this game. It will swallow you whole and digest you without exception.  Mount & Blade: Warband is a 2011 RPG by Taleworlds Entertainment. While other RPGs only pretend to let you tell your own story, Mount & Blade actually does.  In the war-torn world of Calradia, you play as an entirely customizable character.  You can decide to either  a) help one of the six fractions, b) one of the six claimants for each throne,  or you can  c) create your own faction entirely by yourself d) be a peaceful merchant instead.  Most of the time you travel around the poorly presented, yet big, but negligible, map.  You visit various lifeless towns and villages, on the quest of gaining renown and money. You talk with lords and ladies, you capture and sell lords, you fight raiders. You win or lose tournaments, you get rekt by bandits when you simply wanted to visit the horse merchant. You receive a small, yet enormously rich village by your king which you find devastated by an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who somehow managed to teleport across the entire map. You travel with your mates Jeremus and Artimenner who start ♥♥♥♥♥ing around who is the better doctor. Following a group of soldiers who promise some mighty fine loot, you discover that you have nothing to eat, because the chicken you had bought have rottened.  And at the end of the day, when it's already 3AM you finally manage to turn away your face from the monitor and ask yourself: What have I done? Shouldn't I have spared this group of poor villagers?  ALL HAIL TALEWORLDS ENTERTAINMENT Mount & Blade: Warband really isn't a perfect game. It's graphics are short above awful, combats are sometimes deeply frustrating, quests are repetitive, the lords and ladies of Calradia all seem to do the exact same stuff, feasts resemble an exhibition of Gunther Hagens' 'Body Worlds'... The list of cons is near infinite. But at the same time, Mount & Blade is a perfect sandbox. You can do whatever you want to. If you are a fan of RPGs like me, you are going to love this little gem.  Although it has a few years, it still holds up pretty well. That is, if you ignore the graphics and some of the clunky mechanics. When I first found it some years back, I thought it had an interesting concept that I had never really encountered before in a medieval-type RPG, like choosing your background and what drives you to do what you in the story. However, it has little to no importance to what happens during the game, unless you are actually roleplaying an avengeful warrior that was born as a street urchin.  I would have liked to see an cross between those elements so that your own story could be even more rich. Perhaps the loved one you lost was murdered by a specific (that the game chose, or you chose, going as far as choosing the motives maybe?) lord of a faction, and seeking vengeance against said lord is sort of like your 'main objective' until you confront him (and kill him?). Better yet, you should be able to have a menu where you could actually stipulate your objectives, and a narrative would be drawn from it. Maybe the lord begs for his life and persuades you into helping him overthrow the higher-ups, until the end, where you stab him in the back and become lord of all, while tales of what you did could be told in the inns of many castles. Then again, that's just my idea of what would make this game even better.  Pros: -Medieval period, which means a lot of bloody combats and diplomatic confrontations.  -You can have your own faction/kingdom, including territory that you can capture, your own House sigil, and even a bride if you are into that sort of thing!  -Awesome sieges and different tactics that you can employ by giving commands to archers/infantry/horsemen.  -A wide variety of scenarios (Desert, Snowy Hills, Green Mountains, and even Steppes).  -Interesting combat where you can parry your opponent and attack in different directions.  Cons: -The A.I. shows its age, and it's not the best. The enemy often just charges towards you (or whoever they are targeting) in a barrage of blows like mindless zombies. They don't really strategize and usually break formations when the fight happens, and when it does, there isn't much... beauty, if we can call it that, in the swordplay. As an example, if you are the last person standing, the enemy will often form a line while they are after you, instead of trying to surround you. It's almost like they are the Cliff Racers from Morrowind!  -There should be more variety in the conversations. After the 200th time you are talking with a lord or a peasant, you start to get bored of seeing the same options and doesn't stick out.  -Although there are different factions, (that resemble Barbarians, Khans, French/British knights, Vikings and Moors), they don't really have distinct customs and manners of speech, which could spice up the conversations a lot more. In the end, they are all the same besides the different armor/weapons/territory/flags.  -Customization. In an RPG, you should be able to customize your character to the best of your liking, but the truth is, almost all of the characters are kind of ugly to look at. I made many attempts to make an elegant knight, but failed miserably. Come on, at least let me dye the hair in different colors!    In the end, if you like the setting and enjoyed playing the demo, I believe you could have dozens of hours of fun with this game!

Mount and Blade Warband.  Short: Phenomenal, fun, many hours to be had, medieval fighter.    Medium: Warband is a game set during the early-high medieval period. It hass a multiplayer and singleplayer game where you control your character. In singleplayer, you have a giant map of Calradia to roam and conquer, do quests, and become the new king. The multiplayer is solely combat-based, no map, just combat funtimes.    Long: Welcome to Calradia, a war-torn piece of land split between the Rhodoks, Nords, Vaegirs, Swadians, Sarranids, and Khergits. Each faction with its unique weapon choices. IE. Rhodoks with their kite shields and crossbows, Nords with their axes and round shields, Khergits with their horse archers, Vaegirs with their sabers, Swadians with their great swords, and Sarranids with their spears and lances. Each faction also has unique armor. Rhodoks have a more militia-style armor, favoring cheaper and less durable clothing, Swadians with their stereotypical medieval armor, Sarranids with an Arab-style armor, Khergits with a Mongol-Arab style armor, Vaegirs with their Russian armor, and the Nords, with their Viking-style armor.   The singleplayer is a giant map of Calradia, with towns and cities dotting the map. From there you can recruit special NPCs or regular levies or occasionally mercenaries. As you fight with those troops, they gain experience, and with that, they can use it to upgrade their armor and weapons to a higher tier, or take a different upgrade path. With them, you fight bandits who roam the map, and when you are strong enough, you can fight a noble, and attempt to capture them (Or start a war) and ransom them. With a rather in-depth diplomatic system, running from noble to noble to invite them to your war path is interesting. Quests are endless, although many are mundane, there are a few special quests that grant large rewards.  The multiplayer is a bit different. Multiplayer is a combat-oriented system, you join a server and fight. Gamemodes range from epic two-team shield walls to gladiator-pit style free-for-alls.   Warband has many interesting mods to offer, so take a look!  Now. Go forth and become the king of Calradia!

Starting as a nobody, choosing your background and your skills you are thrown into the land of Calradia. Your goal may be to terrorize villages, live as a mercenary or perhaps you prefer to serve as a Lord for your king or queen. You can do that and more in this medieval world, all from a third person perspective.  Mount and Blade allows you to recruit your own army from various kingdoms, along with special compagnions that you can grow your own way. While doing that you can travel the land choosing to gain favour in villages, cities or from lords and rulers. With patience you might even start your own kingdom. The game features real time combat where you can control your attacks using your mouse. There are a wide variety of weapons ranging from sabres, straightswords, lances, axes, polearms, javelins, shields etc. As you play you can develop your weapon skills, customize yourself with armor and choose your skills.  When you start out you will be a weak and unimportant character with no band or army to support you so you will have to head out and recruit villagers. As you fight battles against bandits and fulfill tasks for cities or lords you will soon grow your character and army to rival established lords and kings. But having a large army is not all, you can change how lords see you, improving your relationship or deteriorating it based on their personality and your actions. The more friends you make the more you increase your chances of becoming a powerful lord or ruler.   If you have finally settled into the world you can decide whether you want to join a kingdom or start your own. Once you join a kingdom you can help them fight wars, capture castles and towns or rebel against them once your ruler has done you injustice. Just make sure you are prepared before you proclaim yourself as king, before long other rulers might see you as a threat and declare war.   This game gives you a lot of freedom in what you want to do, it requires a ton of patience and many hours but all the politics and tournaments, battles and so on make this a very enjoyable game. There are too many details to explain but you can influence your army size by your own renown and skills in the land and improve your army by upgrading individual recruits, training them and so on. I started off as a 50-man mercenary army but after a few months I joined a kingdom, made a name for myself and about 1 ingame year later I have proclaimed myself as a ruler and conquered many cities, castles and villages. Now lords serve me and I am on my way to become the one true ruler of the land, ending the conflict between the existing rulers.  In short, requires patience, uses real time combat, involves thinking, planning and strategy but will provide you with a very long open game.

If you are thinking of buying this game but the dated graphics mean a deal breaker for you, then you are about to commit the biggest mistake of your life.  This is one of the best medieval combat/strategy games I have ever played.  If you’ve ever wanted to experience what it must have felt like to lead a group of men into battle to further your ambitions then this is the game for you.  You customize everything about your character including his or her physical features as well as his or her background and skills, and then quickly set off on your adventure. You’re a nobody at first and very few but the most desperate are willing to flock to your banner and cause but that quickly begins to change as you slowly but surely begin to make a name for yourself in Calradia. You get the freedom to play however you want, from becoming the loyal vassal to the king of one of the many countries in the game to a rogue bandit lord pillaging and burning his way trough everyone that crosses your path, eventually carving your own country out of blood and steel. The combat is amazing, and very responsive. It all takes place in third person so you can lead your men and fight from the front line. It might take you a little bit to get used to it since it has a bit of a curve, but once you learn it it’ll be the richest experience you’ll have. There’s a ton of community support and mods for it that are extremely varied. You can play a mod that adds a fantasy element, a mod that lets you play as a common soldier that joins up with a Lord’s army and fight for him, a mod that turns the game into the Crusades or lets you lead your own Roman Legion, or fight in Japan during the samurai era. My personal favorite has got to be the Game of Thrones: Clash of King’s mod that drops you into George R.R Martin’s Westeros during the War of the Five Kings. You can recruit men from any of the seven kingdoms or across the Narrow Sea and pledge your loyalty to any of the houses playing the game of thrones.  It’s a great game, and I cannot recommend it enough, if you’ve ever wanted to experience leading men into battle in the middle ages, feeling the exhilaration of storming a castle and putting each of it’s defenders to the sword, going from being an orphaned gutter rat to the king of the entire continent then this is the game for you.

Mount & Blade: Warband Is a genuinely entertaining game, The Mount & Blade series continues to deliver all the action and strategy you want in this installment. Overall Mount and blade provides decent character creation, a good amount of RPG customization (e.g. stats and skills galore) and a relatively large world to explore. The combat in Mount & Blade: Warband is similar to games like the 'War of the' series (Vikings, Roses), or the Chivalry series.  The strategy and the scale of battles however are much larger. In Mount & Blade; Warband, battles can have up to 250 players, so that in itself can be crazy hectic fun, and gives the multiplayer a unique edge over the rest of the games mentioned in this review. I have got to say though, if you get a chance to play any of these awesome games take it, only you will know how you feel about each game, and Mount & Blade: Warband brings a unique flavor of strategy and action combat to the table.  I figure I should close this review off with a little bit of info, as of this review,  Mount & Blade 2: Bannerlord is in development, so you may want to be excited for that!

Fairly amazing open world Midieval RPG-sandbox game with a focus on large scale outdoor combat and sieges. This is actually one of the more engrossing RPGs Ive ever played - but I dont consider myself a big RPG guy so take that with a grain of salt. You just have so much control over youir characters actions and overall destiny, it truly feels as though you are playing a role and not some prescripted story with some minor branching like many modern big budget RPGs.   Speaking of budgets, I guess this game didnt have one when they developed it initially, but it became immensely popular despite its myriad flaws. There is still absolutely nothing like it on the market. Armed with a bit of resources, the Warband expansion helped the developer add some graphical poilish and even more depth to the role playing as well as online multiplayer which I have not yet tried but can only imagine the insanity of.   In many ways an old school throwback game, with very little instruction given to the player and high combat difficulty (make sure you set combat to 'Normal'), this wont appeal to everyone. But for those who want a real taste of the Middle Ages, this game puts something like Assassins Creed to shame in its ambition, length, and scope. Truly epic, Mount & Blade Warband is a unique, classic RPG thats not for the faint of heart!

EDIT: Downloaded mods. I WAS SO WRONG.  EDIT: Played this game again....  I tried to get into this game, really really hard. I will admit that it isn't good for the first 5-6 hrs but can you really blame me for quitting? Although the mods are great, the singleplayer is kind of dull. Let me explain.  Most of the singleplayer has you running around and doing favors or quests for the Nobles and Lords around the area. However, sometimes you'll be doing the same quests over and over and/or just hunting down the bandits in your way. As much as I really wanted to get into the game it takes a LONG time to build a good enough army to handle your own kingdom. While I do understand that you just have to be extremely dedicated to doing the same tasks for the same lords and nobles of the area. The thing is, I want to like this game, but I can never dedicate myself the hundreds of hours of time required.  Don't get me wrong, it's not that I am not into these games. I guess it's because I've played this game before: Feudalism 1&2 which is a flash game. Basically the flash version of this game. Feudalism just felt a whole lot more organized and less messy or random. While MB has a lot of features that the flash game rip-off didn't have, it still doesn't make up for the problems it has. Such as traveling. Traveling in this game is much more complicated, slow, and probably worse than the flash game. Traveling in Feudalism was quick, but provided the risk of running into bandits. Traveling in M&B provided the risk of fighting a superior force, but while traveling is risky it can end up being costly and wasting your time. Sure, there's a risk and a challenge but when you invest all that gold and time into getting your armour, weapons, companions and army... aaand it's gone. There will be times when you will HAVE to fight mounted ronin raiding the area and there is no way you could've ran away. It becomes a grindfest trying to get it all back, it's like rolling a boulder up a hill only to have it roll over the other side.  The quests are either incredibly boring or they will sometimes be too tough for you to handle. If you want to speed up the game, the game sees it as a cheat so you have to configure that in the launcher, which is annoying. Bandits that run around will be either 10 or so men or 30-50 men. Countless times I've lost an entire army to these fights and keeping only the elite veterans and even then... even then those fights don't give back the money you've lost.  The combat is nice, and commanding your men is awesome. The game can be a cluster♥♥♥♥ though, and just numbers will win outright most of the time. My problem isn't the combat, but rather just the singleplayer experience. Doing quests and favors for lords can be boring, tedious and if you haven't played the game before you won't know where to find a certain criminal or bandit party. Sometimes you don't really know what to do other than a vague description.  So, why is it this important? Because leveling up doesn't feel very rewarding or great. Yeah you get a few points for your stats, but the fact that you have to tediously grind bandits, do boring quests, quests you don't know what you're supposed to do (until you look up a ♥♥♥♥ing guide) or tasks that are impossible to do at low levels... It doesn't feel great, at all. It doesn't feel good looking in the store staring at the armor and weapons I can never buy because everytime I build an army it gets killed by bandits, then I have to build it up again if I want to stay alive, it's slow and I can't advance forward to being a Lord or a peasant that grew up to take over the Kingdom.  I feel like feudalism was a better game. The items and abilities you could get if you played enough, the awesome looking armor and the special troops you can recruit for conquering certain towns. The items for sale in M&B feel like random items pop up when I'm in a town. Certain weapons or armor sometimes disappear from shops (replaced by other items) so I can't buy them and I have to travel to another town. The Lords and Ladies of the land don't seem to have different personalities (they all basically say the same thing and do the same thing) and towns don't seem to be varied at all (Like having certain swords or armour for sale or different towns breeding different types of horses, etc.)  So, I bought the Napoleonic wars dlc and yeah I don't really feel that dignified getting it. I did it for the MP since that's all it seems that everyone plays and it's absolutely nothing like I expected it would be. No teamwork or formations, no organized charges, just a bunch of guys shooting and stabbing each other haha. Sadly, I kind of think Chivalry: Medieval Warfare does a better job at that as much as I'd hate to admit it.  Is it worth the money? At full price? No. Buy it during steam sale.

This game managed to make me play it for over 100 hours and still think 'This could've been so much better.'. This is going to look like one of those reviews where the guy writing the review has several thousand hours in the game yet he's talking about how bad the game is...  This is technically a terrible game. Models, textures, UI, writing, animations, programming, controls... All terrible. (The music is fine although a bit low on quantity. Gotta give'm that.)  What makes this game so appealing for all of us that plays this game is what it features. It's a game that lets you go out, build an army from nothing, use that army to either side with a Kingdom of your choice or murder anyone in your way to have political importance in the continent as you capture forts and cities.  You build up your own character much like in any other RPG by levelling up certain stats and gathering better equipment over time. But when in a fight, the game almost has this RTS feel to it where you command your army as you march in front of them.   Or actually, in the middle of them. Getting bodyblocked by your troops. Every... Time...    You can witness armies with hundreds of men clash and fight to capture a fort. It geniunely feels amazing and makes you forget about how incredibly poorly developed this game is.  So, yeah. If you're into the type of game that I explained in the three pharagraphs above this one, this game is your best bet until a new and well developed game comes out. (Hopefully Mount & Blade: Bannerlord, the upcoming game in the franchise.)

I have always loved the idea of rising to the top as 1 person and being just that 1 person on the battlefield as a commander, so that made me wanna try mount and blade warband a lot.  When you first start this game out it will probably give you quite a hard time since the tutorial barely explains anything to you or give you any indications as to what you should do next, but thats the beauty of it, if you push through that rough patch at the beginning with barely any money, weak fighters, bad equipment and everybody looking down on you it will become great... let me rephrase that even the phase were everything you have sucks is great, but it will get better if you push through that.  After grinding quests from lords, villages and cities for a while and killing looters, sea raiders, steppe bandits etc you will be looking to get an enterprise ( a steady income for you so you can pay for your group of soldiers ) and from then on you can probably start out being a mercenary shifting the land to your favour.  You can help the nords defend against the veigirs or help out the sarranids against the khergit khanate and all that good stuff.  To sum up the good things and worse things about the games I will just make a pro's and cons list.  Pro's:  - The game is absorbing and interesting - The gameplay is good on the map its just pointing and clicking and the combat feels fluid and great - if you like medieval settings ( dont confuse this with fantasy ) this is the game for you  Cons:  - I can look past this personally, but the graphics aren't really all that great certainly not bad, but not great - Can be really frustrating when you lose your soldiers and your companions start leaving because you lose them ( which is the beauty of the game and this could be a pro aswell as a con ).  Cant think of any other cons right now though  Conclusion: just buy the game.

Tl;dr version: Your money or your life!  Note: The pros and cons are mainly based on the singleplayer. Some things about the multiplayer near the end.  Pros: - Has a lot of depth to the game.  -Your decisions for the most part matter. One example is like choosing whenever or not to release a lord, or take him prisoner when you defeat him. This can lead him to like you more, or dislike, depending on your decisions. You can't always choose the simpliest option.  -You are right there in the thick of the battle or sitting in the back commanding your troops as they take to the field against the enemy (which can range from several guys to a full on army).  -The open world map is large, with multiple areas to fight in. On the open world map, everyone is either running around, sitting on their ♥♥♥ doing absolutely nothing, or constantly picking fights with each other. It's overall chaotic in the world of Calradia, but you just can't see it (unless you use cheats). Not the greatest looking overworld/map, but it's not that bad.  -The combat is quite fluid and satisfying. Using the mouse to swing and block in four directions is simple and fun. If you are going to play the singleplayer, then do it right. Go to your options, turn the damage of you and your allies to normal, turn off auto block, and experience Warband with all of it's ups and downs :)  -Become the king/queen of Calradia. Who wouldn't want to become one? Just make sure to keep in the realm in check or else you might have some problems on your hands.  -Tons of mods to choose from, although the Vanilla game can last you for a very long time. and other such things  -Pretty good music. Fits the game.  Cons: -Not the greatest looking game. If you are looking for graphics, then this isn't the game to look for.  -There isn't really a story. You basically create your own story/background and then thrown into the world of Calradia, where 6 different factions fight for control over the realm.  -Can get quite repetitive, since all you are doing for the most part when it comes to the gameplay, is running around on the overworld, and fighting other parties.  -Has no real tutorial, and does not tell you about what it has within the game. Basically you need to either look up a guide or explore the game in-depth, in order to figure out what the game has to offer. Don't be to suprised if you've missed something or experienced something new after hours of playing the game.  -Siege battles are not great. Definitely not the strongest part about the game.  -Getting knocked out isn't fun. Neither is being taken prisoner (since you cannot die). Try and not get screwed over, or you will be put in a rather bad position.  -You may get graphical issues with the game, like having part of the overworld turning into a blue sky. It isn't game breaking, but can be kind of annoying.     All of that was, for the most part, the singleplayer part of Warband. The multiplayer:  -Involves the combat system like the singleplayer, but with other players (obviously). It can be a blast, and quite chaotic if you can get on the populated servers. Watching 30 players charge into another 30 is quite a beautiful sight to behold, wouldn't you agree?  -Having a few men and woman swinging away in their undergarments is entertaining to watch. Especially if those players are wrecking ♥♥♥♥ :)    What else is there to say about this wonderful game? The combat is smooth, the gameplay is fun, there is alot to do in it, the multiplayer is chaotic, and the only thing lacking is a basic tutorial and not so good graphics. The pros heavily outweigh the cons and the only reason why you shouldn't buy it is because it isn't your game. So yeah, it's pretty much a must buy.  Still holds up well for an old game.

Aimed at addressing realistic medieval combat, Warband delivers mounted combat, specialized troops, sieges and vicious factions that change their mind more often than a woman picking party clothes.  It's not all sword and blood in Calradia, up-and-coming heroes with short arms and long pockets can also dabble in the seedy world of economics with trading, purchasing industries and upgrading their properties.  Socialite? Intrigue and deceit await you in the halls of powerful rulers, making friends, marrying elegible nobles and backstab until you reach the top!  The down side? Multiplayer can be entertanining if you can find a properly administered server. A flimsy vote system, easy-to-exploit crutch mechanics and scarcity of world-wide servers can make the multiplayer experience an excersice in futility.  Warband may lack the finesse and depth of big developer titles, but has laid a solid foundation for better future development.

This is my very first review, so please be gentle.   Let's start with the bad, get that nastiness out of the way; The game is *very* overwhelming at first. (to be continued) Quests you can't finish. (eg: My small army of 50 moves fairly slowly, stop giving me tracking down missions...)  um... mediocre graphics....and.. um... peasants repeat lines.  The good...it's all good.  The negatives I mentioned only affect you if you want to impress local lords early on and align yourself with a kingdom (which, LOL, turns out to be a mistake).  Trade is simple and straight-forward. Buy here, sell there... Starting businesses is easy, but expensive. So win some tournaments!... Tournaments are unique to the region you are in (so is the arena) and the pay is quite decent. Combat can be adjusted to suit you. AI difficulty, blocking mechanics, attack mechanics etc. Find what works for you, and you will decimate all.   Overwhelming, this game really is. You start off as a nobody. (To borrow someone else's words) you are not the Dragon-Born, you are not The Witcher, you are not Neo.  If you want something, you need to take it. You want military dominance? Then you need to raise and train your army. Trade? You need to do a lot of travelling. etc.  This game also has no clear-cut objective, you can literally spend your entire time playing on your own wasting time.   So decide your path and what kind of person you want to be. Play to those desires and everything will be pretty :-)

You know the story, war is brewing in a distant land, you play the foreigner/stranger person and you magically become the king of everything! Well, there's no magic, and it's not quite that simple.  Mount and Blade: Warband is the expansion, if you will, of the original M&B, where the primary difference being that you can command a party as small as Robin Hoods band of Merry Men to a massive army boasting over a thousand troops (hope you have enough resources to support that). This series is the epitamy of roleplay, where you can be anything from a humble peasant, to the greatest master of trade, to a greedy mercenary, to the damned king/queen (yes, you can play a girl). The game runs along the feudal system of the medieval age, where if you don't have a d*ck in your pants and nobility to your name and blood, you're essentially nobody (it doens't go quite that far, but you'll be surprised at how tough it is). Now, the base game is good and is fun to play, but the real beauty of this title are in the mods, and if you don't play at least one mod, you're not doing it right. Mods expand the game and add new roleplaying abilities to the game. My personal favorites are A Clash of Kings (A Game of Thrones mod, albeit, it's taxing, buggy, and the developer is one of the unfriendliest humans ever) and Brytenwalda (turns the world into a historically accurate 6th century or whatever United Kingdom gripped by all-out war), and I usually play as a bloodthirsty mercanary or a bandit king/queen (playing women is so fun). Never shy away from a commoner's background or to play a female, because that's when the game gets interesting. So strap on your sword belt, sharpen your blade, and mount your horse, it's time to enter the world of Warband.
