Worth buying at at least 50% off via my 'Never buy games at full price' motto and 'Percentage-to-hours' hypothesis (accounting hours played and enjoyment in regards to the absolute lowest percentage that I would consider buying it at if I suddenly lost the game and had to rebuy it).   Pros: The combat is very hard to master, especially ranged combat, but works well. Quests add replayability to the game and, while side quests, they add to the main storyline which is whatever you want it to be. The flexibility of a Choose Your Own Adventure allows you to play without walls and major restrictions, so you can be as evil or as nice as you want to. The level system allows you to make your character how you want it to be, and you can change from full agility to full strength if you wish. You can't perfect everything without major grinding, and this makes the game challenging. The game has modules that is Workshop supported, meaning this game is heavily reliant on mods, my favourite being Perisno. The modules represent what type of game you play in Warband, the default and main game being 'Native.' The modules add nice campaigns, weapons, characters, and multiplayer aspects. The DLC is 100% not needed, but adds a lot of content if you wish to buy it, notably in the Multiplayer section of the game. The characters, while bland, add to the story and are actually important unlike some RPG NPCs, which are more one-off. This is because relations are very important to getting a higher standing in the realm, so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ off one guy might ♥♥♥♥ off a lot more of his fellow brethren in his faction, and this can put you at a disadvantage.  Cons: The game loses saves via corrupt files too often, and is too common of an issue to ignore completely. Sometimes this can be avoided by saving multiple times, but if that's something that is required, it cannot be discounted and is definitely a detriment to the game. When Englishmen left their homeland for the new world, they brought with them charters establishing the colonies. The Massachusetts Bay Company charter for example stated the colonists would 'have and enjoy all liberties and immunities of free and natural subjects.' The Virginia Charter of 1606 (which was largely drafted by Sir Edward Coke) stated the colonists would have all 'liberties, franchises and immunities' as if they had been born in England. The Massachusetts Body of Liberties contained similarities to clause 29 of Magna Carta, and the Massachusetts General Court in drawing it up viewed Magna Carta as the chief embodiment of English common law. The other colonies would follow their example. In 1638 Maryland sought to recognise Magna Carta as part of the law of the province but it was not granted by the King.

Still the best medieval simulator, hand's down.  Mount & Blade: Warband is what I wish Wars of the Roses, Viking Age, and Chivalry might grow into someday.  I keep waiting for a newer game that even comes close to M&B:Warband, but nothing comes close. This one has it all, weapons physics (attacks actually do different damage based on direction of swing and your velocity relative to the target), RPG-style skill improvement, a colorful cast of NPCs, an (admittedly rudimentary) trade economy, an interesting setting with multiple factions, diverse troop-types, and a completely open-ended sandbox world. Do you want to earn glory and lands serving a noble liege? Become kingmaker in a bloody civil war? Declare your own claim to the throne and conquer the world? Just ride around plundering caravans? All of the above are possible.  The only downsides are the graphics (not bad when the game came out but a bit dated now), the rather weak AI (pitched battles tend to have the tactical depth of a soccer game with 5-year-old kids where everyone converges on the same point and starts hitting each other), and a repetitive late-game (the early game is very fun and interesting, the late game is still challenging but you end up fighting a plethora of siege battles on the same castle map again and again).

Imagine a hybrid of Medieval: Total War and Chivalry: Medieval Warfare, and then throw in massive sandbox and RPG elements into the mix. In Warband you take the role of.. well, honestly, whomever you want to be.   Do you want to gather up your army and roll around the map killing bandits or burninating the peasants? Or would you rather pledge yourself to one of the many kingdoms and become a lord? Maybe you'd prefer to aid one of the pretenders onto the throne in a grand coup, or even go entirely independant and forge your own glorious empire?   All of this and more is possible in warband, but the really interesting thing is how the game actually plays. Initially you cruise around a campaign map, in the style of older RPGs. However, when you enter a battle, the fun begins. Yes, you have your own army, and you can give them tactical orders, much like Total War. The unique thing here is that you don't take the role of some sort of omnipotent flying general; you are in the battle itself, in a 1st person perspective.  Combat itself is fairly satisfying- attacks are made by left clicking, with the direction of the swing determined by your mouse movement. Likewise, parrying is directional, and requires fairly precise timing. Enemies can be caught offguard with a swift kick, but bear in mind that this will also leave you vulnerable for a short time. Advanced players can also feint, changing the direction of the swing at the last second.  However, it isn't all hitting peasants with swords. The variety of weapons available is massive and includes: swords, axes, clubs, warhammers, knives, halbards, polearms, spears, lances, javelins, bows, crossbows, throwing knives, throwing axes, and more. Of all the different combat styles, I found lancing and horse archery the most satisfying. Lancing as heavy cavalry is huge fun- get up some speed and charge at a knot of infantry and you become and unstoppable juggernaut, skewering foes like so many kebabs. Horse archery is probably the most difficult playstyle, but also the most rewarding- travelling at speed on a horse affects different weapons signifcantly- it'll impart momentum to melee swings, allowing you to lop off heads with axes as you charge, and projectiles will also inherit your velocity. As such, arrows won't go where you expect them to, until you get used it it.  Graphically, the game isn't brilliant, but it's functional. There are numerous graphics enhancing mods around that help with this. Speaking of the mods, the modding scene for this is fairly massive, and there are some mods and modpacks around that really change the game. The best of these is probably the Floris pack, however, I've had issues running it with the steam version.  tl;dr: very much worth buying, but only if you're prepared to sink a lot of time into it

Having played this game for a little while, I found it to be a challenging, if stupidly fun game. When you begin, you arrive in a new land with not much more than the clothes on your back, but eventually by doing quests and with practice and time, you can become a powerful leader (or a cowardly lion, like me) and lead a band of misfits around the land of Calraidia, helping or hindering the factions and peasants you come across as you please. Its even possible to take over a town- or if thats not enough- fight your way through the opposition to get to the top of the food-chain and become emperor, (not that you have to of course, but always worth a try).   The individual factions are a great idea, with each having their own strengths and weaknesses, this means that if you want a versatile army, you have to travel the land and recruit from villages owned by them. This can bring problems for you though, if the particular 'brand' of unit you want is found only in hostile territory (e.g an area infested with bandits or a faction that is hostile to you.).   Another fun thing with this game is the way that combat works, though it may have a steep learning curve, those who master the various weapons and tactics availible can become unstoppable.....unlesss you come up against 300 Rhodok Crossbowmen, nothing can survive that. Sieges are also a fun aspect of the game, just hope that you have a good axe or bow, keep your head down, and maybe you'll survive long enough to watch all of your allies get wiped out by Vikings :D.  All in all a fun game, just read some of the many guides availible if you want to really do well in the game (I'm pretty terrible myself) but skill isn't required to enjoy it. Just sit back relax, and begin your adventure.

I wrote a review for Viking Conquest so i figure I might as well make a review for this though there's really not much for me to say. This is a game set in a medieval environment where you start as a freelancer and get to fight for or against 6 different factions who have very different troop trees and ways of fighting. Wide variety of different weapons to play with and if Native gets too boring or easy for you there's a wide variety of mods like Floris, Nova Aetus, Gekokujou, Brytenwalda, Pendor, Perisno, Light and Darkness (the only mod with a story that I know of so far), and many more. There are also several good mods that are still in development like Silverstag and L'aigle (this is a mod that takes place in the Napoleonic Wars) that you can count on being good once they're complete. If medieval combat sounds interesting to you then this is the game for you.  Two things of note is that while most computers that aren't 7-8 or more years old can run Native, many mods improve the textures which is great if you have a relatively more modern PC (not a gaming rig, but something that's decent by the standards of around 4-5 years ago) but a computer that could barely run Native might not be able to run a mod that's more graphically intense like Floris. Also, spears are rather weak in this game since the face-hugging AI will get right up next to you making it practically impossible to hit them (you can try thrusting your spear in a slightly different direction from the enemy and then immediately re-direct the thrust to the enemy once the spear is moving). I can see this being annoying to spear fans and HEMA enthusiasts but...nothing can be perfect. Although, in Viking Conquest, spears get a new overhand thrust (you can do it the same way you'd do an overhand swing with a sword, by moving the mouse up before clicking the attack button) that will hit an enemy no matter how close they are.

It is a Medieval Sandbox game which involves you recruiting people from Villages and going all Hero Mode and fighting Bandits, helping Villagers and doing jobs for towns. You can also sell your sword (or whatever weapon you wish to use) to one of the many factions in the game, 6 in total, who are all competing for complete dominance in the land of Calradia.  Firstly, we have the Kingdom of Nords. The Nords are Vikingish people who majorly rely on their Heavy Infantry, the Nordic Huscarls. In my opinion, thease are the BEST (and I mean the BEST) infantry units that you could possibly get. Their position in Calradia, is in the North West. A word of warning, even though this faction is pretty much the faction that all beginners will join, the game is made to have this faction ALWAYS, ALWAYS, trying to be at war with any faction. Secondly, we have the Kingdom of Vaegirs. Russiany Axe Wielding, Bow using merry men who live in the Snowy areas of Calradia. Along with a few villages and a city of the Nords, they are terrorised by Sea Raiders, who plague the Coasts. Becareful when fighting them, as they are the strongest, and most dangerous bandits you can run into in this game, but also carry some AMAZING start loot, and can be used to XP farm for your men. The Vaegirs also boast the Best Archers in the game, the Vaegir Marksman, who's only possible equals are the Sarranid Bow Masters, who we will get to later. This factions position, is in the North East.  Thirdly, the Kingdom of Swadia. A mix between English and possible French, who are in the very middle of Calradia. In my opinion, they are a faction I would not choose to join, because due to the fact that they are at war, any faction they go to war with, will be right next to them, meaning you would not get a break, unlike the Nords, who if they were at war with the Rhodoks, would get some breathing room, as they would be a kingdom away from them. The Swadians also have the Best, but most expensive, Cavalry in the game. The powerful Swadian Knights! The Sarranid Mamlukes (who we will get to later) can also possibly give the Knights a good challenge.  Fourthly, the Kingdom of Rhodoks. They have the same origins as the Swadians. They rebelled against the Swads and founded their own Kingdom in the mountains. They are a nice beginner starting area, and possibly a very nice faction to join, as long as they are fighting in their own land. Their position is in the South West of Calradia, in the Mountains. They have the strongest crossbowmen, and have some very decent infantry, who mainly carry Spears. The Rhodok Seargent (Sorry if that is spelt incorrectly) may be the Second best Infantry, if not the third. Their Crossbowmen, the Rhodok Sharpshooter, is the best Crossbowmen in the game, beating the Swadian Crossbowmen. A mix with their Crossbowmen, along with some Vaegir Marksman and Nordic Huscarls, could become the strongest force in Calradia, especially if mixed with some Swadian Knights and a few Sarranid And Khergit Cavalry. Also, like the Nords and Vaegirs, are under siege by some powerful Bandits, the Mountain Bandits, who do have some annoying units, but also have some nice loot and can be used to get some early starting XP.  Now to the Sarranid Sultanate. Deserty people who have some very nice Cavalry and Archers. They are in the South East part of Calradia. Just look at the Deserts and you will see them. You could say that their Mamlukes are equal with the Swadian Knights, and are better than those knights, as the Mamlukes cost less to pay for. The Sarranid Master Archers are also the second best Archers in the game, with the Vaegir Marksman being the first. Their special bandits are the Desert Bandits. Horse Riding, Lance wielding people who are very annoying, especially when you have a poorly equipped and upgraded bunch of soldiers. They can be used to get a nice bit of XP, but their loot in not impressive.  Finally, we come to the Khergit Khanate. People who possibly take after the likes of Ghenghis Khan (I think so, and no racism is meant). Mostly all their units are horse riders, so getting across Calradia, and the battlefield, will be no problem. They mainly rely on their Bows and Lances, and are horrible when attacking a Castle or Town, so becareful when using them when on the attacking side of a siege. They are also in the middle of Calradia, but just a little to the right. Honestly, I would not join them, because if you are attacking a well equipped army of Rhodoks (which most games I have had, the Khergs and Rhods are at war) your Lancers could be decimated by their Spears, and any remaining units would be shot down by their Crossbowmen. The special bandits that are in their lands, are the Steppe bandits. Like the Desert Bandits, they ride horses and a quite a few may use Lances, but most of them will be using Bows  So in the end, the faction of choice is yours.   In Conclusion, I find this game highly addicting and enjoyable. The only downside, is that it may take time to get to know how to play this properly. But trust me, once you get to know how to play, you will be playing it A LOT!

An excellent sandbox rpg game. Game lacks superior graphics in today's world, but makes up for it in immersive gameplay. Start out as a nobody, then rise and become king! You recruit men in your party, battle other regiments, and gain xp, gold, loot -- albeit, not with magical properties or extreme value -- and level up. And it gets better... You can upgrade your units so that they become stronger.  One cool concept about the game is the relations. You build prestige or hate with nobles, or factions, and can earn fiefs, or towns that you earn money from, and can garrison troops. You can even rob other nobles, and start wars with other factions. (Do not recommend this if you have a low reputation with your liege king) Even in the boring stage, you can hire heroes other than yourself, get married, learn poems, and trade.  One downside is the parallelogram of gameplay. Sometimes, it gets too repetitive. But, ignoring that if you can, it is very enjoyable.  There is multiplayer in this, but I have not played it, so look to other reviews for more info.  The game too hard? No problem. Just increase the portion of damage enemies can give you. (This works in reverse, too) Too small a battle? Done. Just increase the battle size to pit your 100 against their 100 instead of a 20 to 20. The AI too predictable? Increase AI difficulty. (Tactics wise, it does get tricky in battle.) Also, when doing this, don't attempt to eviscerate 10 archers with just a two-handed blade. It goes south pretty fast.  Dozens of mods to choose from without having to spend 15$ on a half-asser DLC.  10/10. GET THAT GAME. I MEAN IT.

Mount and Blade: Warband defined the best of RPGs of 2010. Start out with one main character, gather your companions armies, befriend lords and court ladies, and then strive to become the richest merchant, the most brutal lord, or the scourge of the world. You must have quick reflexes and a patient demeanor though, else you find yourself in a prison for a week and lose all your abilities. Warband is fun and addictive on easy mode and unforgiving on hard, so it is a welcome to causual and experienced players; the relatively low graphics of the game make it laptop friendly. Plus, the game is steam-workshoppable, so many users have recreated vastly different scenarios -- from Gekokujo (war for Japan's Shogunate of 1500s) to the American Civil War to The War of the Five Kings (A Game of Thrones). This makes the game's replayability high and enjoyable. I recommend Warband to anyone who loves adventure and rpgs with a little dash of strategy.

Light of the hearth and sconces warm and cast a hue across the battered old stones of the keep. Centered in the room -- a large table spread with an elegant dinner fixed fresh by the many servants of the king. Smiles and stories of conquest wasp through the air with the smells of roast pork and fresh breads.  And here am I, amid lord and lady, a son from no noble birth. I was a studied lad in my youth, but intellect makes no matter in turning a lord from a peon. Still, I've served under my liege, King Harlaus, for near a full turn of the seasons. I had proven myself to him through simple errands and by winning a tournament not unlike the one we had participated in on this day.  Proud of myself and my accomplishments, my reward thus far has been two small fiefs. Despite them, my Lady Sondel, the one who holds my heart, seeks a man of true endeavor. I must make more of myself. I want a castle, or something more than simple peasant villages. Though I try my best to care for them, they are too often raided by the enemies of my king. He calls me to battle upon which my return is met with ashes and death.  There was a rumor of one such raider. A certain Lord Crahask.   Now, here's where things get interesting...  I stand amid this cheery and bubbly room of richly garbed lords and nobles, only to sight Lord Crahask in the distance. After saying my words to Lady Sondel, the only other person I truly cared to see, I turn and approach the honorless Lord. This fool is no longer an enemy. He fights for my King. Upon starting conversation, the brigand immediately condemns me for my courtship of Lady Sondel and a clear rift forms between he and I. Previously, I thought my grudge was merely one-sided, but now I know more. He tells me of his own long pursuit for the hand of Lady Sondel. In an attempt to avoid more confrontation, I decide to move from that conversation, give my farewells to Lady Sondel, then venture from the castle. Perhaps a walk will cool me down.  While sauntering along the dirt paths within the keep, I turn to a quieter area away from the bustle of the shops. I hear the sliding of metal across scabbard and the disgruntled arguing of common scum. A group of five men pull bows or swords from their backs and ready themselves against me.   *What is the meaning of this!?* I think to myself.  I press back around a wall and aim my bow at one and take him down with two arrows under his shield. By then, two others had closed in and I pull my sword from its sheath. The first blow I dodge with a back-step. I lunge in only to have my attack deflected and the man at his side begins to lunge in at his advantage. I pull back and lift my shield to glance off one, then another attack from either man. I see an opening and swing my blade, a hit, a block, then another swing and the man crumples before me. Now, one man is no match for my swordsmanship. I dismiss his life to the floor and head to the street corner wall I had moved behind. When I look out, I see the other two men with bows and arrows at the ready. I ready my own and poke my head out once again. *Zip*, *clack*. An arrow finds its way past my side and into the stones of the wall behind me. I notch my arrow, aim, loose. The shaft of the arrow visibly vibrates as the first archer's skull lurches back, arrow embedded in its depth. The second archer loosed two more arrows in my direction, but my own two met his chest.   I decide to search the bodies and come upon 500 denars.   Hm... Perhaps a payment from someone who wants me dead. The timing is truly impeccable.

Yes the game play is pretty old school, but there is SO much to do, The value to this game is outstanding. There is a certain satisfaction that this game gives you that I have yet to see in other games (Watching a horse rider topple from his mount when you hit him vitally with an arrow or javelin, Or charging full speed and landing a mace blow straight to your enemy's face.) This series of games just does something for me I've never seen in a game before, it's pretty magical.   You can be a bandit and raid caravans, you can be a merchant and build quite a bit of wealth, you can become a vassal for a king and be granted lands, you can get married, you can turn the vassals of another kingdom to your cause with some fancy convincing, OR you can start your own kingdom and gather followers through positive influence, or you can take the land by force. I suggest checking a wiki, some of the routes you can take are not very intuitive.   On the downside, I kinda wish there were more options in the ways of diplomacy and resolution, once a territory decides to go to war with you, the only way to get them to give it up and leave you alone is by smashing their entire kingdom to bits, or by coaxing vassals to join your cause, which (depending on the kingdom) can be nearly impossible to do. I also don't like how often enemy vassals escape from a defeat in battle, since when you are defeated in battle you almost ALWAYS get captured... Very annoying. I also wish there was a way to garrison villages or dispatch patrols without using vassals.   Over all, I would definitely recommend this game to anyone with a bit of patience and bloodlust. If the looks of the game put you off, wait for the new game to come out, it looks gorgeous and they may even address some of the negatives I brought up. Definitely worth a good look for anyone who loves midieval style fighting.

M&B:W is a great single player experience, that takes some effort to learn, but the payoff is well worth it. Multiplayer is fun too (according to my son) and it works well with the Oculus Rift DK1. Here's my journey:  I got this game (and the original) a long time ago, for like a buck. It is easily worth full price, but it took me a few years to figure that out. I installed it, was confused by the overhead map, and absolutely sucked at combat. So, I uninstalled it, and forgot about it.  Then I kept reading little bits and pieces about it here and there. I thought, did I miss something? So, I re-installed it, and was still confused, and I still sucked at combat. I did bother to check out some mods, and was impressed with the Star Wars mod for Mount and Blade (not Warband). Still, it got quickly uninstalled, and forgotten about yet again.  Then, my son was looking for games to play with his Oculus Rift (I'm too old for that crap), and I bought M&B: Warband for him. Well, I decided to re-install it again, so that I could maybe help him with any technical difficulties, pick up the trading cards, and just to check the game out again, it had been more than a year. Well, third time was the charm. I took the time to start figuring out the strategies of the overhead map part of the game, and spent some time learning the combat. The amount of depth in the base game alone is amazing, and the combat is very gratifying. Not to mention there are many well made mods that add plenty to the game to keep it fresh for a long time.  All I have played is single player, but according to my son, who doesn't like the overhead map bit at all, but loves the combat, multiplayer is great fun as well.

This is the most disempowering simulation I have played.  That is not, to say, that it isn't also an excellent simulation. It's a mediocre game, but a phenomenal simulation. Maybe not for its efficacy of allowing you to do what you want, but for its complete obstinance in making that anything other than easy. If you have fantasies of living in a medeival land and being a roamnig hero, beholden to no-one and helping the common man, prepare to be bored out of your mind. The peasants mostly want to be left alone, and when they do want things it's things like grain. Or cows. And when they actually have problems you want to help with, like bandit attacks, they don't ask you to hunt bandits for them. They ask you to teach them how to defend themselves. Everything they ask for is reasonable. That's what makes it so numbing. Eventually you abandon your desire to be a roving, solo hero. (Perhaps you are sick of being run down and gored to death by a practically untrained mercenary who just coincidentally owns a horse, which elevated him to the status of a god. So you get a few friends and wander with them instead. You do some good deeds. You train some peasants. Whatever. Your small warband starts asking for pay. You realize you can't just keep a dozen skilled warriors on retainer without producing an income. You start working for guilds. Then lords. Your warband grows.  Flash forward a bit and you're collecting taxes, refusing to give the collected taxes to the lord you're collecting them for, razing villages and selling their valuables, growing rich on your mercenary war-profits by collecting pay from a liege whose wars you never actually help with and going mad with transitory power.  I mean, if you want power. And frankly there isn't much else to aspire to, despite the level of simulation. Sure, you can romance a few noble ladies. Or men, depending on your gender, but they predictably require far less romance. But that process is ardurous and takes agonizing months if not years of letter writing and 'visits'. 'I need to see you, love!' 'I am here!' 'Okay, later!' +3 affection.  Wow.  Maybe you want to lead a kingdom. Become a rogue power taking castles and villages and coming to lord over a vast army.  Well, your army size is limited by your Leadership. Better grind that. Not that it matters, your enemies scale so their armies are always bigger. Lords who you need to woo into your service take months if not years of letter writing and 'visits'. 'My friend, we should speak!' 'Okay.' 'We have spoken, goodbye.' +1 affection (sometimes). So...you'll never in any reasonable timeframe get what you want.  So it's an excellent simulation of medeival life. You can't really get what you want. The most effective short-term gains come from screwing over peasants, and your success can be instantly destroyed at the whim of a lord that glanced at you across a field and happens to have a larger army.  Who am I kidding? The game's rigged. They -all- have larger armies.  ...actually, that doesn't sound very simulationist.  Worth playing. Not at full price. Thank god it's on sale all the time. Don't spend more than five bucks.

Mount & Blade: Warband is probably one of the best games available since Minecraft. The reasoning for this, is its long playability and it's easy modding. Mount & Blade, as a game was meant to be modded which makes it a great platform to essentially play any game that you want.   Another fantastic feature, is the ability to have large battles without very much lag (obviously this depends upon your computer and graphics settings, at least to some extent). Most other games auto resolve combat or never even touch that type of combat because it would make the game slow to a stuttering crawl.   The low graphics have been brought up as being a detracter from the game (which in my opinion is a not an excuse). the reason for the low graphics, is that the massed battles would kill most any low to middle end computers.   I have played close the 300 hours and I do not see myself stopping anytime soon. I might be done playing the base game (which is pretty fun in its own right), but there are many mods left to play.   I highly recommend this to anyone interested in medieval warfare and/or RPG's.  Thank you for reading, and I hope you find this review helpful.

The multi-player only contains the battling portion of the game, with a team deathmatch and siege mode.  The game also heavily supports modding. The only negative is the graphics.

Mount & Blade: Warband is an action / role-playing / strategy / medieval simulation - game developed by turkish developer TaleWorlds Entertainment.  I personally love this game and spent way too much hours on it, while never having stopped to have fun with it. Let me start off with the world map, which is pretty decent in size and variation. At the beginning of a new game the world, named Calradia, is split up in 6 factions: Kingdom of Nords, Kingdom of Swadia, Kingdom of Vaegirs, Kingdom of Rhodoks, Khergit Khanate and the Sarranid Sultanate. Those six factions are able to wage war on any other faction, even if the player doesn't take part. Every faction has it's own ruler and vassals, which can also change (I'm not sure about the ruler, but I've never seen him change). You start off alone in one of the big Cities and meet a merchant right at the beginning of the game, after you've been ambushed by a few bandits you can kill pretty easily. He gives you a quest to gather a few fighters in order to rescue his sibling, who is held captive in a nearby bandit camp. That's how you're thrown into the game. Now you have the choice what to do, you don't even have to help that guy. You could choose any faction you want and join it, as soon as you fulfilled enough quests for the respective leader of that faction and your party is big enough. You can expand his kingdom and hope to get some villages or even your own castle, if you're a very good fighter you may even get a whole City. But if you don't want to fight for a permanent income (Or you want to just invest in the future) you can also get a few businesses in some cities. Depending on what the surrounding villages produce a brewery for example can give you 400+ denars (the currency in the game) per week, or even cost you some money. Trading is part of the game and in every city you can go to the market for a few hours and just listen to the merchants and find some profitable trading routes for yourself.  But you may ask yourself now what the actual goal of the game is? Well the answer is pretty easy... Conquer EVERYTHING.  Build up your party, while being vassal for one of the rulers and if you feel strong enough tell him to f*ck off and then you start conquering every castle and city for your own kingdom. You can also promote your companions to vassals or 'steal' some from other factions. Or you help one of the throne claimants (every faction has it's throne claimant), but I never tried this so I sadly can't tell you anything about it.  To be honest, this game has pretty damn ♥♥♥♥♥♥ graphics, but at least it will run on a toaster from 1990...  The audio is acceptable and the soundtrack is very enjoiable, but is not guaranteed to run the whole time it should...  The controls are easy and you can get fast into commanding your fighters in the battle.  All in all this game definetly has more potential, but is astoundingly good and a deep medieval simulation, but the sequel (M&B II: Bannerlord) promises to give us everything that is still requested. If you think you could like this game, get it. It probably still is a long time until Bannerlord is released, since it's release is to be announced...

If you want to 'live' out something akin to a stategic conquest game where youget to fight and order soldiers, which is immensely addicting and a whole lot of fun, then get this game. It has some flaws, yes, and the graphics are dated, but a lot of this can be fixed thanks to the amazing modding community which has created so many solid mods. There are complete era and map changes, that come with their own gameplay dynamics (and the existent gameplay dynamics are very fun). The game IS an RPG, and while I wouldn't compare it to Oblivion or Skyrim for example, because it's not complete open world exploration (which is a bit of a shame). It is, however, something that gives you real choice. You can choose to fight for an allegiance or kingdom, or work your way up as a vassal with a fief (a property such as a town, village or castle) and gradually collect more as you fight for them, and this creates a sense of drama between actually trying to get the fiefs (which is difficult as there is almost a fight for them). In that way, you can try to incriminate lords who might want it, losing honour but increasing your chances. You fight in your area against other people with your party. That's just one way to play it however - you can find an heir or claimant to the throne who wishes to claim the throne of a certain nation, and then work with them, and then later betray their trust or continue to work with them. A lot of human greed and human nature falls into it. You can either get greedy or choose to be honourable and fair - and there are consequences and benefits of all of this. I feel that there are some imbalances with this game. You can use a ool known as 'TweakMB' to tweak the game to your likings, but just remember not to overdo it because the game might get too easy and boring (but really, play how you want to). The game can be a lot of trouble and stressful on harder difficulties. I started at an easy difficulty and found a lot of challenge at the beginning, then found it progressively easier (but still somewhat challenging).  The game requires some time investment to know how it works, but when that's all done? Good luck on getting potentially hundreds of hours of your life consumed (although I wonder what else you could be doing that could be better than the hours you spend here).

I signed up my warband with the Rhodoks. King Graveth had the thought to fight a two-front war against the Swadians and the Sarranids. Sounded like a good way for enterprising mercenaries to make coin. More fool me. We captured Senuzgda Castle from the Swadians and we soon made peace with them. Problem was we still faced the Sarranids. Lo and behold, their marshall assembled an army to capture Senuzgda from us.   My warband help defend the castle in the first attack. Their numbers: about 750. Ours, including the Rhodok nobles: 300. We managed to fight off the first attack, but the castle remained under siege, and it was a matter of hours until those dirty, dastardly Sarranids rebuilt their ladders and initiated another attack. They had the numbers, and the first battle wore us down. Defeat was inevitable. All we could do was wait it out for the sake of honor, and when the time came, we would fight to the very last--Then my month-long contract with the Rhodoks ran out. I had the opportunity to resign for another 30 days, or let it expire. I let it expire, left Senuzgda Castle, talked to one of the Sarranid nobles, and signed up as a mercenary. I found and captured a Rhodok noble whose warband was wondering nearby. I joined yet another successful siege of Senuzgda Castle toward the tail end. Love live Sultan Hakim! Long live the Sarranid Sultanate! At least until the end of the month. ;)  Pros: The sandbox aspects create so many unique situations. The writing remains strong despite a lack of narrative focus and surplus of the generic characters (see below). Combat's fun and complex. So many different builds to try. Customizable difficulty accommodates both beginners and hardcore veterans (but keep in mind how changes rebalance skills and stats).  Cons: Gameplay mechanics can be frustratingly opaque (eg. character creation). Diplomacy options are narrow unless you resort to mods. After a couple of hours, you'll begin to realize how generic NPCs all are. Graphics are fine, but it just looks indie-rific, lol.  Final Score: I AM HYPED FOR BANNERLORD. Warband is a rough gem for sure, but its depth and charm make up for any flaws.

Bandits? I VILL DRINK FROM YOUR SKULL! This game is quite unique. It's a grand role-play adventure with no fixed goals, a medieval sandbox of sorts. Help along an usurption? Be a loyal vassal? Get married? Take over the world? Or just run around alone whacking people with polearms? It's all possible.  Battles are a strong point. You are but one man, and strength of numbers is depicted quite realistically; on higher difficuulties, running alone towards an army will get you KO'd in a pinch. Build up your 'warband' of followers and you'll have a much better chance.   Unit types are not strictly enforced, but rather roles are determined by equipment and skill points. There is the 'rock paper scissors' of specializations, to some extent, with archers, infantry, and cavalry, but there is more nuance there too: skirmishers vs. heavy infantry vs spearmen, horse archers, knights and lancers, standard archers and crossbowmen... On harder difficulties, this becomes very important, as does tactical positioning of each unit on the battlefield. You'll want different soldiers for facing an army in an open field than you'll want for taking a fortified castle.  If you're a warmonger you'll often find yourself at a numerical disadvantage; exploiting your field's terrain and the strengths of your units is critical to your success. Variable terrain and constantly changing composition of both your own forces and your enemy's lead to enjoyably varied real-time tactical puzzles to work through.   Tweak config files to turn up the maximum army size in battles, and you'll witness a spectacle. Watching your troops line up across the field in front of you, shields at the ready; or leading a cavalry charge, slamming into the enemy line and taking out the enemy lord with a single blow from your lance; or standing atop a hill and watching the enemy get cut down by your archers as they approach; or stockpiling a force of crossbowmen and have them unleash a hail of fire that cleans off castle battlements in a few volleys; I haven't seen any game match the epicness that can be achieved here.   Behind it all is a large overworld, trading and an economic system, and some rudimentary politics / relations between factions and also between specific characters, which can be enhanced or altered by mods.  In later stages the game becomes a bit grindy. High-end gear costs astronomical amounts of money. The balance of income with tasks such as quests is also not quite right in the late game. To some extent, mods will fix this. Quests, dialogue, and menus in general are a bit messily done.  It's not the most polished experience, but if you can get past the faults and feel the roleplay, I think you could sink hundreds of hours into this game.

Possibly one of my favorite games of all time, Mount and Blade Warband has so much to offer, and so much of it is filled with depth.  The series is often called a Medieval Lord Simulator, and while I'd say the title is accurate for the most part, this is by no means the only way to play. It's more like a medieval life simulator, unless you want to simulate being a peasant in which case there's a gamestop just down the road. There is no structured story in the base game, though Viking Conquest does add one that is entirely optional, the player is left to their own devices. Become a powerful vassal, usurp a king, start your own kingdom outright, become an infamous bandit, or a wealthy trader, the world is your oyster.  The one issue I have is the intra-lord relations are pretty weak, in this respect it's almost like the player exists in a vaccum, the lords react to the player, forming friendships and rivalries with them, but no such system is in place for lords when interacting with one another. It's a trivial complaint but it's noticeable after a while.  Overall, Mount and Blade Warband is one of the best value for money games out there, I've enjoyed my time with it a lot and will continue to, and I've never heard someone say they flat out don't like it.

One of the all time classic games. With shockingly poor graphics for the age and very basic sound quality, this game doesn't seem like it'd be a winner. But it's incredibly deep considering the rather simple interface, allowing for a decently wide array of content to explore.  The combat system shines. Mounted combat, including couching a lance make the biggest frustration in the game NOT finding a constant string of fights. It's a gloriously simple mechanic to learn, but rewards skill and timing the more effort you put into it. Easy to learn, difficult to master.  The range of fighting types is amazing. Spear combat is often overlooked (ie Skyrim) but in M&B it's here in all it's glory. Horse archery, heavy cav charges, mowing down peasants with a mace while you look down from your mighty war steed.  On the fly unit orders are quick and effective. Lead your troops from the front or roam the rear lines barking orders and overseeing the battle from on high.  Companions and leveling them offers immersion in character back stories and in-fighting. When companions sometimes leave your employ, you feel their loss.  The content is far deeper than expected from an indie title. Fight as a merc, swear fealty, rebel and put yourself on the throne. But add in personal relationships, courting the ladies, hosting feasts, trading between cities, doing quests for lords and guild masters, fighting in tournaments, and more....and this game packed with content even though much of what you do is watch a tiny horse move around the world map.  Modding is a big part of M&B. There are some amazing mods out there. Floris is huge but upgrades every aspect of the game. Gekokujo is a wonderful Samurai era version. LOTR, and GoT are both represented as well.  Just get this game. You will not be disappointed.

I've been playing M&B since before Warband and still do. I pulled a lot of hours in retail version, before purchasing WB on Steam and never regretted spending money. Crazy, right? So the vanila itself is fine until you get used to the game. It brings up lots of recognizable weapons and armor design from the most popular cultures of Medieval period to choose from. It gives a satisfying feeling, when defending a wall among your men bringing down scores of men. It's a great feeling to outflank your enemy that surpasses you in quantity (nearly most of the time) with a solid Knight charge. To capture an annoying lord that has been pillaging your village over and over and getting ransom for him. To either become a marshal and bring forth the lords, or try to start your own Kingdom, which is a difficult task at the beginning. You will end up sooner or later (after a hundred or two hours), realising that challenge is basically gone, since you've cracked the mechanics and finally got everything right and start thinking there is nothing more the game can show you. And then you find mods.. Bryttenwalda, Europe 1200, 1257 AD, MP Mount and musket, CRPG, and coop like Nord Invasion and many more, like roleplaying Persistent World. With new features, reworked morale, recruit system. Completely new and quite accurate maps with a lot more Lords, towns and Castles to play through. It's hundreds of hours of fun for such a small price.  And then, there are payed Add-ons, basically mods going in a full fledged release. Not all of them are definetly flawless, they carry many bugs in them and some additional work is always required, but that is only due to the engine problems.  The engine itself is very old now and is not suited to work out so many scripts in huge mods like the 1257 AD I mentioned earlier. All of the new features are difficult to implement properly, especially there are problems with Spawning and Path finding, with high-end machines dying with 600-700 hundred men fighting on the field, with crashes and stuff like that.  Still, it's one of the few games I so highly will and do support with my money, getting all the add-ons.  Since the latest Viking Conquest, I need to mention a few words. 1. I got crashes as everyone else, but applying checkbox in Launcher configuration: Load textures on demand, fixed it entirely. 2. As I mentioned earlier, there are some geodata problems once in a while, where you can fall through the floor during naval battles while making a transition between ships, some invisible walls (bugs) that make your soldiers stuck in one place, until they walk around it. 3. This game has a deep 3rd person medieval battle simulator at its core, with strong RPG-style leveling, map conquest, and some simple questing to build relationship with NPCs. To explain how GREAT this game is, let me tell you the story of a character I just retired. I started as a no-name who got mugged in a big town, and ended as the emperor of the known world. I was a level 1 son of a ruined nobleman with a rusty sword, a hunting crossbow, and a lame horse. I ended as a level 43 king warrior with a coat of plates armor, riding a heavily armored horse, and I could swing my masterwork sword twice per second. Did I mention I was carrying around 2.5 million gold coins and ruled over 22 towns, including the one where I got mugged? My first company had seven peasants with pitchforks and butcher knives. A few months I had leveled up my peasant and had a decent infantry squad supported by deadly but weak archery squad. The battle system is well fleshed out and you can command separately each type of unit and issue them about 25 different commands. When I retired I ran a company of 150 elite cavalry units, the famous swadian knights. I could literally take on companies almost thrice my size with favorable terrain (armored horses with armored warriors on them don't do so well in mountainous terrain you see.) When I retired I had leveled 4 NPC heroes in my company to level 35+. I had made them all cavalry, but I could have made them archers or infantry, it was up to me to choose their skills. One of them was a good engineer to build siege towers promptly, another one had great spotting so that my map vision was extended. I also ruled over 25-ish lords to whom I had given countless villages and castles as fiefs so that they could run large companies, some of them larger than mine. When I retired I was the most famous man in the land. I was also known as a man of honor since I avoided looting villages, freed allied lords and let rival lords go when I captured them on the battlefield. I had won hundreds of battles, some against rival kings and their gigantic companies, and had killed 15,000 foes out in the open battlefield or during sieges. If anything I said here appeals to you, do yourself a favor and pick up this game. Yes the graphics are not that great, but I was having so much fun that I did not notice.

Perhaps not one of the most beautiful RPGs on the Market Mount and Blade Delivers with great mechanics and giving the player all the freedom a Sandbod game set in a medeavil era should.  Starting off it is important to cover this point. There really is no story to be had here other than what your actions cause. This game is driven by the player's actions and that of the many war parties that prowl Calradia. Mount And Blade Warband is about Tactics in both the battlefield and somewhat in the political spectrum. Also with dozens and dozens of mods from a great community this game has plenty of replayability and each one introduces a fresh feel that almost makes the game feel entirely different.   Some mods worht lookign into are:  The Clash of Kings Mod which sets the Game in the world of A song of Ice and Fire (Game of Thrones) The Veiled Stars or the Last Days which both set the game in The Lord of The Rings. Gekokujo which sets the game in feudal Japan Full INvasiojn 2 which is a mod that intrduces a multiplayer cooperative expireance of waved based combat of enemies that vary from Roman Leagions to Star Wars Drones.  The Multiplayer aspect of this game offers somethign exciting and just feels purely seperated from any other game besides perhaps chivalry. Sword and shield, Bow and Arrow or one large Battle axe all fighting in death matches, And even a siege game mode where one tea, defends a keep while the other fights to take control.   Moving back to singleplayer to finis hthis review, this is the core of the game and my favrorite part is the ability to choose a faction to fight for and claim Calradia, or, if you have to gonads for it, fight for yourself and carve your own empire. You start off by choosing your own past varying from a poor street urchen who grew up to be a burglar to being to child of a vasasal who has lost all of their family title. From there however you choose what to do. Do odd jobs for casdh and build a small band of mercenaries or immediately begin working under a vassal or lord to gain favor and be awarded a Lordship and a place among his Vassals. There are even Tournaments and arenas to win you money and reknown. There is so much offered in this gem of a under the radar game that for anyone with hundreds of hours to blow or simply looking to pass some time with a sandox where they can see who would win a fight between a few hundred Pompus Swadians and a few Grizly Nord Berskers can find something to keep them coming back for more.

This game is fantastic - definitely the best medieval combat in any game I've played. Its quite simple to learn, but difficult to master. It makes you feel like a real swordsman as you develop your skills. You can fight as an archer, calvary, or as a foot soldier.  The singleplayer is an amazing sandbox experience. There isn't any real story here, but that's fine - it means you can make your own. You can be a merchent, a mercenary, a vassal, or even make your own kingdom.   In addition to the hundreds of hours you could put into the singleplayer, the multiplayer offers hundreds more. It offers team deathmatches, free for all deathmatches, battles (where if you die you stay dead), duels, and my personal favorite sieges, where one side tries to capture a flag in the center of their opponents castle. The multiplayer is where the amazing combat of Mount and Blade shines. The best players are amazing and will defeat you nine times out of ten in one on one combat, but don't think its not easy to get into. Everyone is friendly and if you stick by your teammates as you get a feel for it you'll soon be fighting with the best of them. I highly recommend looking up combat guides for the game - there are fantastic ones out there for each of the three general troop types (archer, calvary, footman).   This is one of my favorite games - I've put more hours into it than Skyrim. I can't recommend it highly enough.

There is something ever so satisfying about commanding an entire army, and charging into battle with them. This game does not have a set story line, and has so much flexibility, making it very well rounded in what you could be. A marauding looter, going to raid villages screwing over townspeople, and running from the law as you make a healthy profit on stolen goods, a trader who...trades! Yeah, not much more to that one. A lord under a kind alligned with a faction, kind or cruel is your choice, or top it all off as king of the land. Obviously, with all that said, this game is set in a medieval like land, so that is a heads up if I've ever told one. Graphically, the game isn't stunning, but it gets the job done, and a job well done it is. The tracks are far and few between, so it is hard to appreciate the game for that, it does not break the immersion however. Then finally, the key aspect of the game, it is a mix of a strategy game, as you try to figure out the best course of action as you wander the land searching for glory and excitement, or men and war, or riches and fortune, but also manage villages, castles, and even cities, should the King grant you the fief. However, it's not all about managing fiefs, you also have to have an army at your back if you hope to live out in the bandit and war infested world, and you must manage it, and be their leader. The fun part is when you ride into battle with your men, but I'll let you experience the glory for yourself. I highly recommend the game if you're looking for a unique game to play, as this game requires skill, and commitment for progess to play.

Don't take my Steam time as how long I've played this. I had it through other (possibly pirated) means and played for hundreds and hundreds of hours until I finally gave in and just bought it to support the devs. M&B Warband is a game set in a fictional world of Calradia in which several feudal kingdoms each wish for total rule over the realm, and will do whatever it takes to reach that goal. You start, if you don't cheat, as a peasent with nothing more that cheap weapons, some gold, some food, and a merchant asking you to help him out. If you do so, it'll start you with a 'getting the basics' tutorial quest, and set you on your way to carve your adventure. You can do anything you want from being bandits, to leading a mercenary army fighting for whatever side has the most gold, or even break away from one faction and start your own kingdom with its own vassals and ladies. You can fight in tournaments and bet on yourself to earn money and honor. This game has a lot replability, not to mention the endless hours you can get from modding (which is extremely easy, btw.) The only bad thing I can say about this game is that the graphics are sort of sub-par, but they're not really that bad when you look at everything else the game has to offer. This is DEFINETLY worth the $20.  TL;DR: M&B Warband is set in a stage of warring feudal kingdoms, and the player can set out to do whatever he/she wishes. The swordplay is very nice, the content is never lacking in playability, the graphics are iffy, but this game is sooo worth the money.  Verdict: 9.5/10

Companions are a nice bonus, but they are very simplistic and unfortunately unlike other games I am unable to remember a single companions name becaues they are really flat characters with relatively uninteresting stories. The siege battles are amazing, fairly unrealistic due to engine limitations but I havn't seen better; but that doesnt mean they shouldnt improve this feature significantly where possible. Also I think another benefit would be having romances that matter, and actually interacting with said romanced character.   Negatives are the weak companions stories + over companion interaction system. GAME NEEDS MOAR' diplomacy options, more RPG elements. I hope the next iteration has a an overhauled companion system with deep characters. They should also implement more interesting side quests, all the side quests in this entire game feel empty. Towns, Castles, and villages are need many more building options that have more significant impacts on the game. Also I believe it would be beneficial to add some way to tell lords [that like you a lot where to go] the current options are extremely limited and make running a large empire/country/kingdom/whatever a pain.

Warband has its rough edges but is a great game offering endless replayability. It is also one of the few games that makes more out of melee combat than simple button mashing.  Set in a fictional medieval world with six kingdoms that vaguely resemble historic cultures, Warband is part action game, part RTS and part RPG. It´s basically Medieval 2 with a focus on the actions and development of your own character.   Magic, elves and orcs are completely absent. Instead, there´s lots of different weapons, armor and fighting styles as a result. You start the game wandering around on the map, gathering a small warband around you and battling here and there. As you progress, these battles will take on a grander scale, be fought with better weapons and for different motives: where you'll be running from bands of robbers at first, the end will hopefully have you fighting to expand your own kingdom. Multiplayer is also fun, offers a whole bunch of maps and a few different modes, all of which work.   As for the actual combat: Warband is one of the few games that really took care to do melee well. It´s much more than simply mashing buttons like a maniac, knowing when to block, what direction to attack from etc. matters here. Newer players are nevertheless given plenty of options to make things more forgiving for them.  The game does both of its core parts very well: the action is fun and the strategy stays interesting, but gets a little grindy towards the end. It also runs really well on older systems. The graphics are not top notch, but definitely ok and in fact give the game a nice old-school feeling.   All in all, Warband offers you great value for money. Highly recommended to anyone remotely interested in medieval or fantasy games.

If you are trying to figure out whether you should buy this game, the answer is yes. I bought this game through amazon and put 100+ hours into before rebuying it on steam and putting another 200+ hours onto it. Play the PC demo, it will show you what the basic game is about. From there its time to embark on countless battles as you work to develop yourself from a nobody to mercenary captain to a lord to a king.   Combat in this game is responsive and enjoyable. Galloping down the field and delivering a couched lance to the enemy king is deeply satisying. Your army is truly however you want it to be composed. Want to skirmish? Build up a core of powerful archers and harass and distract the enemy forces as you tear them apat. Want to charge? Assemble an army of power Swadian Knights and crush the enemy underfoot. Want to settle down and turtle? Get Rhodok Crossbow and Spearmen and hold the line. You are an important part of each battle and must juggle the roles of commander and powerful warrior.   If you ever find yourself unimpressed with certain game mechanics, look to the mods you fool! Native Expansion, Floris, Prophesy of Pendor, Brytenwalda, Clash of Kings, SOOOO MANY GOOD MODS. Modding in this game is SUPER easy. simply download the filepack, place in modules, and when starting choose the module you wish. Mods in this game are full fledged new games. Native Expansion tweaks and adds to the many bast features of the game, improving diplomacy, fief management, and character options. Floris continues improving, overhauls the graphics, and revamps the troops trees entirely. Prophesy of Pendor creates an entire new world with new lore, units, factions, cities, knighthood orders, rogue adventurers, and MUCH hight difficulty. Brytenwalda changes the setting to 1066 British Isles and has like 60 cities compared to the base games ~15. Holy ♥♥♥♥ does this games mod scene rock by bringing forth the most direct improvements to the game.   Play the game, appreciate its quirks, play the mods, fall in love.

Mount & Blade: Warband overall is an awesome game! Warband uses a combination of third-person/first-person fighting, a couple of RPG elements and RTS management to create massive fights between armies of people while keeping you in the middle of all the action.  The game allows you to join one of the many different and unique factions in game to loot trade caravans, pillage villages, siege castles and much more in the name of your faction. Though you can even take this a step further however, if you are brave enough, by taking on all the factions by creating your own faction and fight for the goal of ruling over all of the land in the name of your faction. The game can have an impressive amount of troops on the screen at a time, making these epic fights that never becomes bored to play, keeping you constantly in the action. Your character can be customized in a great variety of weapons, armor, and horses. Your character can also customized in a variety of skills to maximize both the character's and the army that you control. One other nice addition to the game is the ability to change to either first-person or third-person at anytime giving you option to change between them at anytime.  However, I have ran across many bugs in game for both the PC and the Mac versions of the game, though none of these bugs were game breaking, it was just a little annoying to see. On the PC version, I was having some problems with the map screen textures not working correctly making it a pain to see anything, though this was easily fixed by rebooting the game. On the Mac version, I would sometimes see a gigantic red shadow of myself in the sky when doing the tutorial quest to save the merchant's brother from the sea raiders and I also saw some untextured wire frames for the trees in both the map screen and the battle screens, though this might be fixed in a future patch. Also, the textures in this game are not that good, but the still definitely get the job done.   I would still recommend that you try their free demo first to make sure if this game is right for you, but at the end of the day, what the game does it does fantastically. Its a solid third-person/RPG/RTS-like game with only minor problems and I highly recommend to anyone who is looking for a unique RPG that stands itself out of the crowd.

Tl;Dr: Great game! Sucky graphic and visuals, but the gameplay makes up for it. -- First, I need to say this: The graphics aren't great. Need to get that out of the way. Oh and the music. That also sucks, although you can change it if you play around with the sound files. However, its the gameplay that makes up for it. M&B:W is a third person hack & slach, a RTS and a market sim. You create your charecter and you are ploped into caladria. You choose a faction (6 I Belive) and start there. The tutorial isn't one. You start getting attacked by bandits. The combat is simple Depending on how you swing, you swing in a diffrent direction. There is also a First Person mode, but its only use is if you are crosbow sniping. Then a tradesman helps you out asks you to resque his brother from bandits and then you are off on your own. The world is huge. To move in the map, you click where you want to go and then your party moves there. You can hire vilagers from towns and train them. If you run into a lord they'll talk to you (Or Attempt to destroy you if you have a bad relation with them). Runing into bandits causes a battle. You can also make a living off being a bandit yourself. You can also buy land and make an enterprise. There are often tournaments of some towns. You should start by going to a King and getting a mercanary contract. Gain some renown and become a vassal/jarl/Something. Or instead of the contract gain renown and get a claimant to thier throne. Or make your own faction. Just a warning: this game can get a little addictive.

Mount and Blade is a low fantasy (no orcs or elves here) medieval first person RPG with elements of strategy and empire building worked in seamlessly. While that description alone may sound pretty cool, the execution of this game is what makes it truly remarkable. The combat in this game is spectacular and I dare say is the best melee first person combat in gaming right now. The strategy elements of army building, strategic warfare, city management, diplomacy, and the advancement of your status within a country all add a lot of depth and character to this title. The game's only flaws are its lack of polish in some areas. The graphics are not cutting edge, but they get the job done well. Dialogue options and social questing aspects could have been done better in my opinion - I'm a big roleplayer and I wanted to actually communicate with the characters in the game beyond what was offered. While the game lacks a bit of polish in places, the overall experience is tremendously fun. The game is also blessed with an exceptional modding community - so the sky is the limit with this game. Is it worth a buy? Absolutely!

One of the games I've spent the most hours on. Mountain Blade used to be one hell of a timesink because of its very open-ended nature and incredible modding community. Plus, with M&B2 in development, it's hard not to be curious for those who never touched it and it's bound to bring back some veterans while waiting.  +Good combat. Easy to get in to, but fairly difficult to master on higher difficulties and in multiplayer +Highly flexible difficulty settings: Have your character or allies take less hits for a more forgiving experience, or keep it 1:1 for a more difficult but 'realistic' experience, or make parrying easier by turning automatic blocking on. +Open-ended Single player campaign: Your character can be part of any faction, rise up, betray them or forge your own kingdom. Build your army from the ground up, train them and fight for what you want in this low-fantasy Medieval universe. +Character customisation: Surprisingly deep, tons of RPG elements with a variety of skills and attributes makes it decent for role-playing. +Item and Unit variety: Each faction had a different upgrade tree from their basic peasant unit. There is a huge variety of weapons, from maces to longswords to crossbows to bardiches. If it's a medieval weapon, it's probably in the game. There are also a ton of armour sets available fitting for the fantasy-medieval theme of the game. +Incredibly fun Multiplayer. Difficult to get into, but insanely satisfying because of the combat system. +Insane modding community: From total conversions to add-ons, there's an insane variety on the official forums.  -Poor diplomacy between factions in the singleplayer. It's very bare and consists of two factions either being at war, at peace, or in a truce. No alliances are possible between factions and it's practically impossible to influence the state of war/peace.  -Little to no gameplay for governance, making peacetime insanely boring. The only things you can do related to governance is choosing a marshall (if you are the faction leader) and build some buildings in villages or towns you own.  -Graphics are pretty bad. They look outdated and the textures aren't great either, but the game runs very well even on low-end computers because of that. They're still easy to overlook.  +/-The DLC seem to be very hit or miss. I personally adored the Napoleonic Wars DLC and spent a lot of time doing community Line Battles, but the community is practically dead as far as I know. I have yet to try the newer DLC, but it seemed to have been poorly received on launch, with patching helping somewhat.  All-in-all, it's one of my favourite games ever because of the amazing gameplay, good multiplayer and great modding community. Its replay value is simply unmatched.

I've been playing this game since the first in it's series was in its beta phase in 2006. That's a long development cycle, but the game started as a two-person operation between Armagan and his wife. Since then, the graphical presentation has improved slightly, while the models have remained somewhat behind the curve.   Nonetheless, I consider this game the game of my last decade, with gameplay that is second to none. This is the game that inspired the entire medieval combat simulator genre. In addition to addictive multiplayer arena-style matches, this game also has a robust single-player campaign that is open-ended and not story driven. You make your own story in Warband.  The graphics, while not really pretty or even the best optimized, are good enough to carry the gameplay, which is where this game's strengths lie. There's no other game in the rpg genre that does mounted combat, and melee combat better. It's rare to find a game where you can be the single warrior, among hundreds and in some cases (if you have a strong enough system to support them and capability to mod the game) thousands of troops on the same map, duking it out and cutting down their opposing ragdolls.  I don't know what else to say, I've been playing this game for so long that there's probably a ton in here that I'm taking for granted and not mentioning here. The best advice I can give to anyone who is on the fence, is to try the demo first, that should put you over the fence on whether or not to buy it.

The Mount and Blade series is a shining example of how to make a game for the ages. It was released in 2010, and even then the games graphics was unimpressive. But if you can see past that, it is an unappreciated gem. It is an open world RPG where you move across the world on a 3D map. There are five factions who at the start of the game are equally balanced, but as soon as the game starts they start fighting over territory. It’s almost as if the player’s aura is so bad that it immediately corrupted everyone. The premise of the game is total freedom and you can choose to play the game in whatever way you want. Of course, this isn’t entirely true. It is a game, so there will always be restrictions, but the gamer makes it work because they actually had enough self-awareness to give the central characters backstories, some of which are even compelling. There are a number of NPC characters you can recruit to you party, and they boost your party’s stats. You can choose to do jobs for hire until your party is big enough to take down a fort, and begin you journey to absolute world domination, if you are a Sauron kind of guy. Or you can join forces with one of the disgruntled lords, and help him take back his faction, and the the world, if you are more of Boromir kind of guy. Or you can live your life in peace, and make your living trading goods, if you accidentally opened Mount and Blade when you meant to open EVE online, in which case you might be better off not bothering mate. 8/10 'It's well worth a look' -IGN   I picked up Mount & Blade: Warband on sale during the 2014 Hoiday Sale on Steam. I had recently gotten the original Mount & Blade for free during the  GOG.com  Winter Sale and had been playing it. The original leaves a lot to desire and Warband actually does a pretty decent job of adding more content. The premise of Mount and Blade is simple; You play a charcter who has traveled to the medival realm of Calradia which consists of multiple constantly warring kindoms. You can mind your own business and simply kill bandits, be a bandit, help villagers, or even start your own trading operation. Or if you want, you can ally (or just start and uprising) with one of the kingdoms and TAKE OVER THE WORLD!! (Well, not quite the world, the GAME world.) The graphical differences between the two games are minimal. TaleWorlds has changed some armor and weapons and has added a bigger map with a new faction which is meant to resemble Arab cultures. If you've played the original, you'll also note some differences in how weapons are swung, while they are definitely more realistc, if you are used to the original then it takes some getting used to know when to release the mouse button to swing the weapon. In War Band, TaleWorlds has added more quests and other things to do. Bandit quests are more present, you can get married, the role playing aspect of the game has been improved overall. And the premise of the original game has been preserved as well. Overall, even if you own the first M&B, Warvand is well worth the buy for the added features and I absolutely reccommend it.  100/10 Would recommend to anyone.
