This is a tough one. Not recommending this title despite wasting many, many hours playing it would seem dishonest...so I'll 'not recommend' it with conditions.  I thought I loved what this game was trying to do but after playing it, I'm not sure even that much is true anymore.  The original Mount & Blade was ground-breaking; Warband was like having having three scoops of ice-cream! I didn't even know that was possible! Viking Conquest is more like your brother's promise to return your stuff in the same condition.  Fortunately, they simply modded the best game ever so in the end, it comes out to a pretty great gaming experience anyway but kind of in a, laughing at a B-movie, sort of way. The language and dialogue options are funny and sometimes infuriating, particularly in the early parts of the story. The odd 'SCRIPT-ERROR' warnings seem like something that should have been fixed long, long before it was ever released.  Just when I get really infuriated with the bugs and glitches, something redeeming will happen and make me love this game...just a little bit. For example, while sailing my fleet along one afternoon, I noticed a lord and his ships stuck on some beach and decided to go have a chat. 'What are you and your men up to?' I asked, pretending it was asked in a rather threatening manner. 'I don't know' was his reply and I nearly spit coffee all over my monitor. I thought to myself 'Fair enough then' and continued on my journey with a smile on my face.  There are quite a few oddities in here but I'll try to touch on the ones that stand out in my mind right now. Very few lords appear to have much interest in women. Not only does this cramp the wanna-be defender of ladies' rights style but it also makes for a harsh world when wives are some of the few people who can give you good directions. This rampant 'bachelorism' is making it really, really hard to find people! It also makes the feasts into veritable sausage-fests.   Then there is the racial 'harmony' aspect. Personally, I find this disconcerting on several levels - primarily, this was clearly a decision someone made because the original game certainly made an effort to be much more inclusive and representative of human populations. Everyone in Viking Conquest is white! Every sailor, wool merchant and mercenary. This is simply ridiculous not only from a realistic viewpoint but from an historical and archaeological one as well. Science, archaeology and the historical record itself all attest to the fact that human beings have met, mingled, traded, fought, bred and cried together since before we ever came down out of our trees.   Then there is the cloning program. Whatever cloning technology the people of Skyrim used to make their children, these folks are using to make tavern hosts. Speaking of women...I always thought Irish women were particualrly beautiful, I never had a clue that there were only about two of them and they both look like they could lift an ox with each hand...while planting a field of wheat and giving birth! Lady Mor...she is strong like traktor. Maybe this is why none of the other lords are interested in marriage? We can't all marry Lady Hild, after all.  I think I'm convincing myself that this is more like a recommendation with conditions, instead?   Many of the changes appear to be made by people I have had discussions with in here before. Those 'my Nord Huskarls can beat your (insert alternate for bestest army ever here)' type of discussions. The ones where after exchanging numerous flaming posts, they finally admit that '...IF there were no horses...and no bows...and everyone had to walk everywhere and hit things...THEN my Nords would win'. So they made a world just like that. Everything that made life a living hell for the poor Nords in Mount & Blade has been removed from the game...or at least its simply much more difficult to have those things. Viking Conquest is the poor Nords swan-song. Even so, it's still pretty awesome and I do appreciate learning a different set of skills in order to enjoy this game. I've been determined to develop my archery just to spite the developers though and by about level thirty, I'm only just becoming sufficiently deadly with it. Of course, it's still the same Strong Long Bow I've had since about level four because there simply aren't any other options in loot, shops or for upgrades.  There is also some evidence of genuine historical love. Place names are particularly interesting for example. How much of it is true or accurate, I would never hazard a guess about but it is fun to try and decipher some of it. Somebody clearly put some thought into it. I'm also curious about this 'Cantiga' song now too.   If you are new to the series and looking for a good, story-driven, RPG-type game then Viking Conquest most certainly is not for you! Consider this more of a battle simulator that doesn't work all of the time. Of the many reported hours put into this title, my guess is that almost all of it went into tweaking the online multiplayer aspects exclusively. The single player parts were obviously left for last and abandoned just prior to release. If your idea of a good story is 'Ima gonna beat up everyone until there ain't no more people to beat up', then disregard everything I've written so far.  The BIG drawbacks include instability first and foremost. Ignore anyone who tells you the game runs fine or that it 'may have one or two bugs', etc. So many people have already written about the exact same problems, the truth of the matter is plain enough for anyone to see for themselves. My game crashing for various reasons has become totally commonplace such that I am in the habit of frequently saving my game because I know it will crash at any moment. When you see code spliced into dialogue options, it's a rather clear indicator that the problems are not originating with the end-users. PEBKAC certainly does not apply in all of these cases, sorry.  Another big one that cannot be overlooked is the rigidly confining mainquest storyline. The player is hamfisted into ridiculous scenarios simply because the writers couldn't be bothered to do any play-testing whatsoever. It can only make sense if you slavishly obey and follow it step by step without ever faltering. Say for example, you think...geez, these guys seem tough, maybe I should go level up a bit before continuning? DON'T do that. I didn't find out that I would be given a free ship until AFTER I'd gone to England, kicked many arses and bought my own boat...and then went back to find out about the main quest...Arrrgh. Later, it gets worse, a certain King expects you to swear an oath of fealty to him and unless you do so, the story simply stalls - I already had a King and I liked him, there is no way I was going to give up all of my towns and castles just to find out what the story says about my mom.   Besides, from what little I could gather about her fate, she seems to be doing rather well for herself. Perhaps that is the biggest tragedy of all with this game? The relationship between the player and their mother is central to the entire quest line and I actually couldn't care less about her. That just sounds horrible, sorry mom. It is true though.  Lastly, I have to bring up religion. What a waste of everyone's time. How wonderful it would be to have the option of playing as a blood-thirsty, Pagan warrior...perhaps one day we'll get that option? Having played this game for a little while, I found it to be a challenging, if stupidly fun game. When you begin, you arrive in a new land with not much more than the clothes on your back, but eventually by doing quests and with practice and time, you can become a powerful leader (or a cowardly lion, like me) and lead a band of misfits around the land of Calraidia, helping or hindering the factions and peasants you come across as you please. Its even possible to take over a town- or if thats not enough- fight your way through the opposition to get to the top of the food-chain and become emperor, (not that you have to of course, but always worth a try).   The individual factions are a great idea, with each having their own strengths and weaknesses, this means that if you want a versatile army, you have to travel the land and recruit from villages owned by them. This can bring problems for you though, if the particular 'brand' of unit you want is found only in hostile territory (e.g an area infested with bandits or a faction that is hostile to you.).   Another fun thing with this game is the way that combat works, though it may have a steep learning curve, those who master the various weapons and tactics availible can become unstoppable.....unlesss you come up against 300 Rhodok Crossbowmen, nothing can survive that. Sieges are also a fun aspect of the game, just hope that you have a good axe or bow, keep your head down, and maybe you'll survive long enough to watch all of your allies get wiped out by Vikings :D.  All in all a fun game, just read some of the many guides availible if you want to really do well in the game (I'm pretty terrible myself) but skill isn't required to enjoy it. Just sit back relax, and begin your adventure.

I usually like to recommend games when I get 1 hour of playtime per dollar, and well I did it! I got this game about 1 and a half weeks ago, and luckily I had a long break this past weekend, so I got to play this game a lot and enjoyed most of it. This is a really fun game, but it is a little outdated (which should be expected because it was released in 2010).  What is good: Fighting - I enjoyed this more than combat systems in other medieval games, such as Elder Scrolls games or Chivalry Not Fighting - The non-combat aspects of this game were great. You get to manage your troops, villages, and castles. I think you can do some political stuff, but I haven't really tried that too much yet Content - I like games that can keep me occupied for $1 an hour, this game has done this. Mods - So many mods. I've only tried one, which was supposed to enhance gameplay. I haven't played the game without this mod, but I plan to try some more later Music/Audio - I really like the soundtrack for this game, it fits very well with the game's theam Art Style - I really liked it, it reminded me of Age of Empires III  Meh (I'm not really sure if I can mark this as good or bad): The writing - The writing itself is not bad, but there's not enough of it. This means a lot of the text is reused, making a lot of the NPC interactions feel the same.  What's not so good: The graphics - They aren't great (again because this was made in 2010) Grindy - This is probably an effect of the lack of writing. A lot of text and quests are reused making tasks sometimes feel repetitive. Lacks polish - I'm not really sure if I can just chalk this up to being made in 2010 because some of these problems look like they could have been fixed with a few more hours of bug tests and fixes. Some of these problems include:  - Battles not ending, forcing me to restart my game (this only happened once for me)  - The intro video opens, then closes, then the game opens in a new window (I found a way to shut this off online)  - Walking into spikes, instead of killing you, forces your character to be stuck there forever, or until an enemy shoots you to death  - If you walk into a town after finishing a battle, the people in the town (like shopkeepers) will sometimes puch the air or swing their weapon as if they were fighting someone, realize they're not actually fighting someone, then stop.  Stuff I haven't tried yet, but are probably good: Multiplayer (if people still play this game, this seems like it would be fun) The DLC

Most of the reviews have been praising the gameplay and depth of the game, to the point that's there's really not much more to say on that front. What I want to praise is how - in every way except really the combat - Mount & Blade is truer to history than pretty much any other game I have ever played. The developers clearly did their research (either that, or a lot of developers don't do much). The only real exception to this is the Sword Sisters, because a lot of them don't wear helmets (but pretty much everyone else does. Hooray, realism!). It would be a problem that a historically based game had female combatants that were not an extreme exception, but it takes place in a fictional land, and the game gives a very plausible explaination for it. The female player-character also has a harder start as she proves herself, but after she does that goes by the wayside as one would expect would happen in the real world. The attitudes of the lords - while at times basic and repetitive - are a good representation of nobles as well, and are diverse enough in their various forms of self-indulgence and vanity that you can't always tell if it's intended that they be so loathsome. Also there is thankfully no dual-wielding in actual combat (I don't think you can even punch with your left hand), though it might have been interesting to have one of the tournament variants involve it.  I know most people don't really know about or have any interest in the history - if it's not your cup of tea I don't blame you - but for those of us who do it's heartwarming to see that (many if not all) aspects of medieval life can be mostly faithfully represented without tarnishing the gameplay experience.

I've been a devout Mount&Blade fan for years, going back to the early versions of the original. One great thing about this game is how it sticks so closely to it's roots. The core is combat. There is something very satisfying about the combat.   Many melee based combat games detach you from the experience, where you click a button and your character performs a physically precise set of movements that constitute an attack. Mount & Blade connects you to the combat like no other game, by factoring in the direction of your swing, height, timing, etc to make it feel so good when a hit connects. Defense is also simple but effective, and balancing your attacks with your defense makes each battle a little chess match.  The rest of the game is fairly straightforward basic RPG, stats enable items, favor enables ownership of land, you eventually stockpile enough money and get a big enough army that it all just comes back to combat.  If you haven't tried this game and you like the idea of a sandbox army mangement and combat game, give it a shot.

Quite possibly the best, non-fantasy medieval RPG out there.   Somehow, even though it would seem like a perfect setting for a video game, we don't have many non-fantasy medieval advetures we can play. Mount & Blade: Warband is that game, the one I've been looking for.  You start as either a male or a female noble or a commoner and it is up to you to work your way up. Being a noble right from the beginning gives you a little boost, but if you choose to start as a peasant, that's fine too, it will just take a bit longer to get a decent army, that won't get slaughtered during the first encounter with the sea raiders. One thing to note would be if you don't like tedious work and grinding in games, avoid this like a plague. It takes about 20-30 hours, depending on your playstyle, to get a respectable army and then you are still very likely to get crushed by one of the members of an opposing kingdom (you can choose a king to serve first as a mercenary and later become his vassal), who has three times as many soldiers as you do, backed up by a couple of his friends. Battles of 70 of your soldiers versus 650 of their's is not rare. But let's say you did it. You worked your way up from being a smelly peasant, through serving as a mercenary, raiding villages for loot that you can get ripped off of by the local merchant, all the way to being a vassal, having your own land (be it a village or a town) and be able to tax those plebs you used to call equals. You have enough honor, or too little of it, you have enough renown and right to rule and your liege recently screwed you over by giving that castle or town you fought so hard over to somebody else, ideally, to himself. That would be the perfect situation for renouncing your allegiance an starting your own kingdom. Becoming a king and maybe, just maybe, an emperor of Calradia is all achiavable in this wonderful game.

I've played the original Mount & Blade, loved it so much I bought the sequel Warband! Just started playing it again, but also just uninstalled it again. Yes, it's enjoyable, especially the arena fighting, BUT I'm really frustrated because I love the fighting mechanic's but they need a lot of working on, so many schemes to choose from I can't really find the right scheme to give me a decent fight. Blocking is hit or miss when you need those movements to count, especially when you have 3 or 4 AI's targeting you at the same time.  If they improve that mechanic, because there's nothing bugged that I see, just needs improving, to deliver a decent 1 on 1 abiity to send your attack however you intend it to go in whatever direction you want, that goes for blocking as well; I may consider installing it again!  I used to be so good at this game, then I realized maybe it was because the controls may have been set to 'automatic', but that takes the fun out of developing the skill through the mechanic, which I haven't found in any other game.  Another thing they could improve is the Arena, make it more entertaining, such as give us the choice to spawn with what ever weapons we want. I prefer the heavy sword and the bow, as it is now, Arena fighting is as dry as it was in the original game, you'd expect more from a sequel, in the area of creativity.  I can't give the game a bad review because I like the game, and have put countless hours, but I sincerely wish they'd work on the fighting mechanic's so that when you swing your sword it connects where you want to go, and explain the control options for fighting and blocking, rather than just allowing us to pick the options without an understanding of what they do in the options screen.  Block by mouse movement... Block by movement keys... attack b relative position of enemy...  Combat needs to be fluid and you don't have time to study arrows on the screen when you have numerioius ai's attacking you from every direction, I'm thinking the Computer gets confused and doesn't know which enemy I'm engaged with when there are so many swinging at me.  The Bow needs working on too, because I don't like playing with cross hair's on, in real life there are no cross hairs on a bow, it relies on skill, but without the crosshair theres no way to hit anything, because the aiming mechanism isn't accurate as you would expect. It feels almost like a mini-game to get a decent shot off with the bow.  All in all, it's worth a buy, and worth playing if your not broke and want to have some fun, they did a good job with this game.  I want to see this company come up with more ideals, and not just stick with the Mount & Blade concept, because there is a lot you can do with these ideals they are coming up with, like an awesome massive eco simulator, sorta like monopoly, create like a virtual boardgame. This engine, and its' capabilities would put Monopoly to shame!

This game is pretty darn good for what it does.  Basic idea is that you are a warrior of some kind looking to build your own army, independant or under the banner of one of several kingly type guys. There isnt a whole load of content, its pretty simple, the main feature being the combat and the politics between the warring factions. Theres a ton of problems with the game though, some gameplay and others are more along the lines of flavour and detail  Pros:  Your character can be nicely customised, specifically in character build, you can give your character a ton of health and combat strength or become more of a support character and boost your tactics allowing for more troop advantage or become a surgeon and avoid retraining new Sword Sisters.   You can use a bunch of different weapons, swords, maces, spears, crossbows, longbows. They all have their own strengths and weakness, personally, be thing to do, double handed sword and a horse and just chop guys down with one strike. It always felt the most kingly type thing to do.       As much as I like this game, I have a lot of negative things to say about it.  Cons:  Its a bit plain, its just plain. So, among the the several factions, there are a ton of Lord characters, that basically control a portion of each of the factions armies. There are a ton of them and fairly forgetable. But they dont come across as very dynamic or interesting. You're going to fight a lot of them and you'll kill them in battle a ton of times but they never actually die, they just manage to escape and run away to heal and try to fight you again. They all have their relationship trees though, they have daughters and sisters and brothers and fathers and wives and uncles and whatever else, but they never really say much more interesting things. I sort of wish they were randomly generated, so then at least if you could kill one someone new could take their place and it would be a bit more interesting since it would damage the faction they were in.    Siege battles are pretty ♥♥♥♥. Any zombie game where you're trapped in a room and all the zombies are trying to get through the only door but you can shoot them down as they pour into your room, would be a basic explantion of defense. Attacking is a bit more fun I suppose, but you still have to wait for your troops to get in first.  Regardless, they could be a ton better, unfortunatly, they only seem to allow for one point of attack and its seems to be more of a battle of how many people you're going to sacrifice for a city or castle.    Graphically, its not horrible though I am forgiving when it comes to graphics. I think its environments are better to look at than character models.    There are like 2 different voice actors for this game :C you're gonna hear the same caveman grunts over and over and over.     Its pretty shallow and you'll definitly want more from it which is why the mods are vital to truely enjoy this game. The combat and character progression are fun enought that I've kept playing for a few years now, (a bit over 200 hours at the time of writing). Its a bit of a diamond in the rough and a good one at that if you can tolerate the short comings.

Simply put, this has to be one of the best games I have ever played. Mount & Blade: Warband is medieval sandbox RPG.   Though there is no defined storyline like in most RPGs, this is where the sandbox aspect comes into play; you, the player character, are free to do whatever you choose. If you get bored of singleplayer, there is also multiplayer; it involves fighting in a number of game modes (the most popular ones I've seen are typically team deathmatch and siege in Native).  The DLCs are alright and you can buy them if you wish. Napoleonic Wars takes place during said era and is strictly multiplayer. Viking Conquest takes Native Warband and places it in the real world; instead of Calradia, the game takes place during the Dark Ages (868 is the starting date, I believe) in western Europe (France, Denmark, and the British isles.  However, the most important part of Warband is the mods. There are numerous mods for this game that can be downloaded for free. They come in numerous forms, but they all enhance replayability with their own unique attributes. You can't truly experience Warband until you start playing with mods.  Overall, you should give it a shot. If you're not convinced, just look at the other reviews. Download the demo if you're still cautious. In the end, it really is a great game that you should enjoy. 10/10

Mount & Blade: Warband, in my opinion, is the most innovative medieval fighting game released in this last 6 years. This game uses mouse movement to control your players' attacks and defenses (unless otherwise toggled), unlike any other game in this genre (with the exception of the War Of Roses). The singleplayer and the multiplayer are two different experiences using the same combat system. Singleplayer is the more complete RPG exerience, with customizable armies, companions, nations, entirely open map, and an unforgiving, uncaring world. (Quite realistic.) Multiplayer is mostly combat, with the exception of a customizable avatar and what you bring into combat (essentially your loadout). This game almost reaches it's full potential if you're willing to modify it (singleplayer, anyways).  PROS: Extensive RPG experience, Original combat system, Singleplayer/Multiplayer, Large & active playerbase, realistic, Globally played, Difficulty is easily adjusted, Entirely Open Word, Decent price, Almost 2 games in 1.  CONS: O.K. graphics (This isn't Skyrim, folks), Tendancy to house Bugs, Glitches, and other Parasites, , Difficult to learn, Addictive ; )  In CONCLUSION, this game is worth picking up if you're a true RPG/Fighting fan. On Steam you can grab the entire series for $8-$15.

Okay, before I start,  it's a great game . I have more than 50 hours on it and I've barely started.   But ... if you're on SteamOS/Linux, don't waste your money. There's a well-known memory leak that causes the game to crash. At first, it'll occur after several hours' gameplay and doesn't intrude too much. You can actually see it coming as the graphics start to glitch, and save before it's too late. But as you get further into the game and (presumably) your save file takes up more space, it happens more and more quickly. With over 300 in-game “days” under my belt, I can play for barely a couple of minutes.  The “MacOS and Linux” thread in the discussions has been full of reports of this bug for months (it also makes it hard to run the DLC at all), and nothing has been done. I've been holding off posting a “not recommended” review in the hope that it might be fixed. But I give up. It's obvious the devs don't care.  So, a word to other developers: It's great that we're finally getting decent games on Linux, but this kind of half-hearted attempt does more harm than good. If you're not prepared to  support  Linux, we'd honestly prefer you didn't release for it in the first place.  Brilliant game, terrible port.

I've read about how the combat works, I've watched videos, I've spent a couple hours practicing on a duel server, and... I just can't get it. I think it's partly because what's drawn on the screen bears so little resemblance to what the game thinks is happening, partly because the input scheme is so awkward and counterintuitive, and partly because the mechanical assumptions behind the combat don't make sense. Someone is attempting an overhead cut, and the ONLY option you have is to block overhead? You can't swipe it out of the way sideways? You can't sidestep? And you have to click AFTER directional input rather than during, as you would if your mouse was the sword? I'm sure there are technical reasons they had to make it this limited, but the resulting experience is unsatisfying and frustrating.

Mount and Blade Warband is not a bad game. In fact it is quite fun. The world and enviourment that the player is put into is very immesive. All of this would be great if a large portion of the games playing time wasn't devoted to monotonous tasks. If I had to break it down, I would say:  -50% of your time is spent travelling places  -20% of your time is spent talking to people  -20% of your time is spent at menu screens  -an optimistic 10% of your time is spent doing something exciting  After playing the game for a bit, I have already done most of the quests and become a vassal to a king. I've been on the fence about this game. I hear tell it was made by just two developers, and boy does it show. If you decide to buy this, I urge you get a mod. The native UI and UX is absolutely horrid. Menu choices don't make a whole lot of sense, and my god, is item management horrible. I played with the Floris mod and that made the game much, much more enjoyable.  Sadly though, the Mac and Linux versions experience frequent bugs and crashes. If you're on a PC, it might work for you, and in that case, go for it if it's on sale. But stay away if you're on a Mac/Linux. The game crashes every hour or so, which forces you to play with autosave. That doesn't sound so bad, but the game is unforgiving if you stop paying attention, or get a little too comofrtable. You can go from being a rising lord with a badass army right back to square one. If you have autosave enabled, you can either deal with those consequences, or do a force quit, reload and load a previous save. Starting over wouldn't be so bad, but all the other armies in the game have been progressing right along with you, so this can really be a game ender, especially if you didn't amass enough gold to get re-established. Oh, and there's no way to turn that off once you create your character.  I am usually pretty forgiving about bugs in games and don't normally write negative reviews because of them. If a game is still in early access, or the developers are still working on it, I'll give them a pass. However, I haven't seen anything in the way of an update for this game, and from what I can tell from the forums, the devs have been/should be aware of these crashes for about a year and a half, as of writing this. I know they're currently working on M&B Bannerlords, so I have little faith this game will ever get patched.  It really is a shame, because this game has so much potential. I understand that PCs are better for gaming, but if you're going to sell a game on a platform, you'd better gorram support that platform. I will probably buy M&B:Bannerlord, but only if the devs have gotten their ♥♥♥♥ together with OSX.
